Though backpackers hike the trail most frequently, it is also open to visitors who want a shorter hike through the heart of the dunes. Follow the orange trail markers with a spade symbol into an area of beautifully varied dunes and vegetation. The trail requires hikers to climb over several steep dunes and loose sand. There is no shade, no water, and no toilet facility along this trail. The average completion time is 1.5 hours.

Length: 2 miles (3.5 km), round-trip
Trail Marker Color: Orange
Trail Marker Symbol: Spade
 Average Completion Time: 1.5 hours
Difficulty: Moderate
Distance from Visitor Center: 6 miles (9.7 km)
Restroom: Two vault toilets at the trailhead

Before setting out on foot at White Sands National Park, please view our Hiking Safety Tips.
audioDescription: This trail begins at a parking area at the side of the road. Near the start of the trail the parking area is edged with a split-rail fence. In front of the fence is a tall, three-sided kiosk with three graphic panels. To the right of the kiosk as you face the trail is a picnic shelter and table. At the far side of the parking area is a small restroom building. Near the beginning of the trail is a small sign that reads, “Parking for Backcountry Camping. Permit required. Available at Visitor Center.” The trail is marked by flat, four inch wide, orange posts with a spade symbol. From the kiosk, it follows a low ridge on the right, across a flat area, then up a slope to a sign where the trail splits to make a loop. That sign has a map of where the camp sites are located around the loop, sites 1 – 5 to the right and 6 – 10 to the left. At that point you are surrounded by the white dunes rising and falling on all sides, with distant mountains visible both to the west and the east. The dunes are bare white sand, often with ripples across their surface. In between are small flat basins with some clumps of grass, small bushes and an occasional yucca plant.

title: Backcountry Camping Loop Trail Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many restrooms at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Backcountry Camping Loop Trail restroom with its recycling and trash receptacles.
images.title: Backcountry Camping Loop Trail Restroom
images.caption: The Backcountry Camping Loop Trail restroom is adjacent to the trailhead.

bodyText: The Backcountry Camping Loop Trail restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, a dumpster, and trash and recycling bins. It is within a parking area with plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs, and there are accessible parking spaces directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is at the edge of a large gypsum sand parking lot. When facing the doors of the restroom, visitors can see rolling white dunes with sparse vegetation behind the building. The doors face a large parking area with white dunes off in the distance, as well as a gypsum sand road called Dunes Drive. Next to this restroom is a blue recycling unit and a large dark brown dumpster.

title: Balloon Area Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many restrooms at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Balloon Area restroom along Dunes Drive.
images.title: Balloon Area Restroom
images.caption: The Balloon Area restroom is located along Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The Balloon Area restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, and trash bins. It is within a pullout parking area along Dunes Drive with space to park automobiles and RVs, and there are accessible parking spaces directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is next to a gypsum sand road called Dunes Drive. The building is surrounded by large white dunes, with sparse vegetation scattered throughout.

title: Beating the Heat - EKO Stop 10

images.altText: The burrowing owl shows off its yellow eyes, brown feathers with white dots.
images.title: Burrowing Owl
images.caption: The burrowing owl shows off its yellow eyes and ability to turn its head all the way around.

bodyText: Unlike most owls, the burrowing owl is most active during the day. Living below ground helps to keep them cool when it’s hot outside. They tend to live in small groups called a parliament. In people, a parliament is a group of leaders who make decisions. In owls, the name comes from their association with wisdom. The owls take turns outside of the den watching for danger. Burrowing owls are known to eat insects, small mammals, and lizards. They will line the entrance of their burrow with mammals scat before they start nesting. Making it easy to get insects at the entrance to their burrow instead of hunting for them.
audioDescription: There are many Hoary Rosemary Mint and Skunkbush Sumacs in this location. They are not as big as the plants you have seen so far but are raised from the ground slightly and have hard sand under them. In this area, animals that want to dig a hole in hardened sand to make a home would have plenty of places to choose. It is sheltered slightly from the wind, so the plants do well here.

title: Big Pedestal
listingDescription: This is one of the largest pedestals accessible by foot at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: A ranger stands at the forefront of a large gypsum sand pedestal.
images.title: Big Pedestal
images.caption: Measuring up at over two stories tall, Big Pedestal holds true to its nickname.

bodyText:
Towering at over two stories tall, Big Pedestal is one of the largest pedestals at White Sands National Park. 

For more information about pedestals at White Sands, visit the Plant Survival Strategies page.

title: Bring on Snow, Rain, Sun, and Wind
listingDescription: This interpretive sign showcases the many ways that weather helps create White Sands' gypsum sand dunefield.

images.altText: Sign that explains the different weather events that help shape the dunefield.
images.title: Bring on Snow, Rain, Sun and Wind
images.caption: Weather shapes the dunefield around you.

bodyText: Weather shapes and makes the dunes. If one key part doesn't happen the system won't shape or make new dunes.
audioDescription: This three and one half foot by one foot sign is mounted on the platform railing at the end of the boardwalk. The left side of the panel has an illustration of what happens in the dune during wet seasons. The right side shows the process during dry seasons. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “The Making of White Sands, Stage 3. The impressive dunes you see before you started to grow 10,000 years ago in a process that continues today. It starts with the 250-million-year-old gypsum that we can see in the mountains around us.” The illustration on the left end of the panel shows White Sands with Lake Lucero at its western edge located in the valley between two mountain ranges. Clouds produce snow over the mountains and thunder storms in the basin, with rain and snow-melt flowing in to the valley. Text reads, “From Sky to Earth. Snowmelt and rains dissolve gypsum. It drains, mostly underground, and settles down here in Tularosa Basin. With summer monsoons or heavy snows, groundwater levels will rise above the surface. Lake Lucero, a large, mineral-rich temporary lake, reappears southwest of here.” The illustration on the right end of the panel shows the same scene with the sun blazing overhead, leading to water evaporating. Winds blow from west to east. Text reads, “Crystal Magic. When the gypsum-laden water evaporates, fragile selenite crystals grow on the lake bed. Crystal shards, lifted by strong spring winds, collide and shatter, again and again. They eventually become the white sand that piles up into dunes.” Small images show selenite crystals, an oblong column with flat sides, and the resulting particles ranging from larger pieces to fine sand.

title: Chihuahuan Life Roadside Exhibit
listingDescription: The "Chihuahuan Life" wayside at White Sands National Park highlights the coldest and wettest desert in North America.

images.altText: The "Chihuahuan Life" wayside, located along Dunes Drive.
images.title: "Chihuahuan Life" Wayside
images.caption: The "Chihuahuan Life" wayside is the second wayside on Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The "Chihuahuan Life" wayside, located along Dunes Drive, features several of the plants and animals found in the coldest and wettest desert in North America.
audioDescription: This 4-foot by 2-foot sign is mounted on two wooden posts at the edge of a pullout along the road that winds its way into the heart of the dunes. The land behind the sign is flat, scrub-covered desert land, stretching out to the distant mountains in the east. On the other side of the road is a narrow strip of brush-covered land backed by low dunes with low, bushy vegetation on their slopes. The top half of the panel features an aerial view of this area showing the entrance road winding its way from the highway at the right into the heart of the dunes at the left, where it makes a loop. Labels at the top identify the changing landscape from the brown-colored Chihuahuan desert at the right, through a changing innerdunal zone, where the brown shows streaks of white, into the heart of the dunes which is totally white. A label marks your current location about tow-thirds of the way along the desert section. Across the middle of the panel is text in both English and Spanish that reads, “All around you, Chihuahuan life. The coldest and wettest desert in North America. This desert covers a vast area. The whole Chihuahuan Desert is 133% larger in size than New Mexico. You can find typical plants and animals like these in three U.S. states and five Mexican states.” Along the bottom of the panel are photographs of 4 different desert plants and one animal. From left to right, first is a cholla. It has thick stalks about 1 inch across with short stalks branching off, the surfaces covered by spones. Next is a picture of a lechuguilla. It has sword-like fleshy leaves rising from a central base. In the middle is a picture of a soaptree yucca with its mound of flat, sword-like leaves and tall stalks with bunches of white blossoms rising above. Next is a picture of a creosote. This bushy, green plant has small leaves on thin branches. At right is a picture of an earless lizard. Its back is brown dotted with yellow specks and its underbelly is white.

title: Cool to the Touch

images.altText: Small white ripples in sand extend vertically across the image.
images.title: Ripples in the Sand
images.caption: The dunes are constantly shifting and changing, as evidenced by the ripples coating their surface.

bodyText:
The story of dunefield creation starts millions and millions of years ago, back when this area was covered by a shallow sea. Layers of gypsum were left behind as the sea emptied and filled over and over, and you can still see them as light layers of rock in the surrounding mountains.

Water carries dissolved gypsum down to the basin, then evaporates, leaving behind gypsum crystals. Those crystals are then broken down into smaller and smaller pieces until they are the sand you just dug into.

The dunes have been here for around 7,000 years! The secret to keeping all this sand in place is shallow underground water acting as an anchor. Much like a paper towel sucking up water, the dunes act like the paper towel and the water holds them in place. When you feel the wet sand a few inches down, you’re feeling the dunefield’s anchor.
audioDescription: This sign, about two feet wide and one and one-half feet high, is mounted at an angle on a single metal post. The trail slopes down the dune past the sign and the next marker is clearly visible. On either side and behind you, the white sand stretches over the rolling dunes. Clumps of low bushes are scattered about. The sign has a picture of Katie, the cartoon fox figure, in the upper left, with text in both English and Spanish along the top. The bottom part of the sign has a picture of a Grasshopper Mouse, sitting back on its haunches, front paws held up to its mouth. It has a brown back and head, with lighter tan on its belly and front legs. Near the mouse is a shiny black stinkbug. Text at the top reads, “My fierce friends the grasshopper mice are almost 100% meat eaters—that is, if you think of deadly centipedes and scorpions as “meat.” They hunt at night like tiny cats. They claim and defend large territories—the size of 19 football fields. In a fight, they are as quick as lightning. After a kill, they get up on a rock, and let out a lion-like roar. How loud can you roar?” End of description.

title: Cruise the Dunes

images.altText: Vintage cars pass the adobe visitor center and bathrooms on a road with a butte in the background
images.title: Entrance to Dunes Drive
images.caption: The entrance to Dunes Drive used to run between the Visitor Center and the restrooms. (ca. 1960's)

bodyText:
Welcome to White Sands National Park and the Sunset Roll self-guided driving tour! This tour begins from the park’s adobe visitor center located immediately to the right as you enter the park from the highway. White Sands National Park is among the most unique places on planet earth featuring expansive gypsum sand dunes. However, White Sands is so much more than just the dunes. Here life within has evolved against a white backdrop which provides a natural laboratory to study rapid evolution. For human visitors, the Tularosa Basin is a place we come to for insights into our past, present, and future as human beings. This tour will show the value of White Sands as a natural wonder, ecosystem, and a place for human enjoyment. Before departing into the dunefield here are a few more tips to help you make the most of your visit:
 
  • Read up on our hiking safety tips before setting off on foot.
  • This is the last chance to get water! We strongly recommend having at least a gallon of water per person, per day. There is no drinking water available in the dunefield.
  • Always know where you are in the park if you decide to explore the dunes from the road. Take note of the mile markers along the road and which parking area you leave your vehicle in.

Let's hit the road!
audioDescription: From the front parking lot, a two-story, adobe Pueblo Revival style visitor center and restrooms with large, pine log supports extending out of the sides of the building. In front of the visitor center, sidewalks wind through a gravel native plant garden featuring desert-adapted plants such as soaptree yucca, desert willow, and agave. Across the parking lot is an adobe wall with a flag pole and a sign that says "White Sands National Park" in front of the wall.

title: Disappearing Darkness

images.altText: A sign reads "White Sands National Park" with a dark night sky with milky way in the background
images.title: White Sands after Dark
images.caption: After dark, the night sky at White Sands provides breathtaking views of the milky way

bodyText: When and where was the last time you stopped to appreciate a dark night sky? Today it is rare for many people to have the opportunity to appreciate the everchanging night sky, but it is always there night after night whether we take notice or not. When the world shifts to darkness, most of us humans settle into our homes, close our eyes, and go to sleep. Out here at White Sands however, the park residents relish in the darkness. When visitors are done with their picnics, sledding, and taking selfies the park gets dark, quiet, and nocturnal animals emerge to start their day. This is when moths appear, fluttering from yucca to yucca, making sure they will bloom again next season. Bats squeak, flap, and swoop for prey. Kit foxes’ tiny paws scuttle along the dunes, chasing creatures with tinier paws. A bobcat lurks through the dunes, its eyes aglow in the moonlight. You may associate darkness with evil, uncertainty, and danger, but darkness is essential for all living things. The absence of light allows natural rhythms to take place. Artificial light disrupts this rhythm and alters the behavior of nocturnal animals. Imagine trying to sleep with the lights on or getting up for breakfast in the middle of the night. For us, darkness signals the end of the day and for nocturnal animals the beginning of theirs. In the absence of light, they can navigate, nest, hunt, and hide. Beyond helping nocturnal critters maintain their groove, the night sky has been an inspiration since the beginning of human history. On a clear night, how many stars can you see from your house? What can you do to see more? Perhaps a porch light or a bright floodlight is trespassing on your vision. The more artificial light that is near you, the fewer stars you will see. With few large population centers nearby, the remoteness of White Sands makes it an oasis for nocturnal animals to live undisturbed and for visitors to catch awe-inspiring views of the Milky Way. Tonight, and during your travels, we encourage you to keep your eye on the sky. Observe the darkness in different locations and recognize that this valuable resource is disappearing as we sleep.
audioDescription: This trail begins at a parking area at the side of the road. Near the start of the trail the parking area is edged with a split-rail fence. In front of the fence is a tall, three-sided kiosk with three graphic panels. To the right of the kiosk as you face the trail is a picnic shelter and table. At the far side of the parking area is a small restroom building. Near the beginning of the trail is a small sign that reads, “Parking for Backcountry Camping. Permit required. Available at Visitor Center.”

title: Dune Life Nature Trail
listingDescription: This is one of the most explorable trails at White Sands National Park. Follow along with Katie the Kit Fox as she highlights some of the creatures and features of the white sand dunefield.

images.altText: An aerial view of the Dune Life Nature Trail parking lot and trail entrance.
images.title: Dune Life Nature Trail Aerial Photo
images.caption: The Dune Life Nature Trail is a moderate, exploratory trail at White Sands National Park.

bodyText:
The Dune Life Nature Trail is a moderate, one-mile (1.6 km) self-guided loop hike. Though not difficult, this hike does require hikers to climb two steep dunes with loose sand. Follow the blue trail markers with a club symbol. Meet Katie the Kit Fox and learn about her friends on this family-oriented trail. Look for tracks of the animals that call these dunes their home. Kit foxes, badgers, birds, rodents, and reptiles all live in this area. The average completion time is one hour.

Length: One mile (1.6 km) loop
Trail Marker Color: Blue
 Trail Marker Symbol: Clubs
 Average Completion Time: 1 hour
Difficulty: Moderate
 Distance from Visitor Center: 2.5 miles (4 km)
Restroom: Two vault toilets at the trailhead

Before setting out on foot at White Sands National Park, please view our Hiking Safety Tips.
audioDescription: From the parking lot, the hard-packed dirt trail leads through the split-rail fence, past a three-sided kiosk with informational signs and then across flat grassland to the white dunes. The trail then ascends up the sand between two dunes to a wayside sign, where the loop trail then splits to the left and the right. The audio description follows the trail to the left, in a clockwise direction. The trail is marked by flat, four inch wide, blue posts marked with a three-leaved clover symbol. The trail meanders up and down the dunes, which are dotted with a variety of grasses, bushes and the occasional small tree. The footing varies from hard-packed dirt to soft sand. The parking lot is a loop and is adjacent to the vault toilets.. At the beginning of the trail near the parking lot a brown sign reads, “Dune Life Nature Trail. This one-mile loop trail winds through the edge of the white sands, where dune life is most abundant. Watch for the tracks left behind by various desert animals as they hunt for food among the dunes. Two steep climbs will be encountered on this walk. Summer temperatures can exceed 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Take plenty of water and protect your skin from the sun. Please lock your car.” Further down the trail another sign warns, “Stop – Stay Alive. Water required for this trail. Take 64 ounces or two liters of water for each person in your group. When your water is half gone, return to your car. Warning Dangerous to hike above 85 degrees Fahrenheit.”

title: Dune Life Nature Trail Kiosk Panel
listingDescription: This kiosk panel highlights information about one of White Sands' most popular trails.

images.altText: The Dune Life Nature Trail kiosk panel at sunset.
images.title: Dune Life Nature Trail Kiosk Panel
images.caption: This panel offers an aerial view of one of White Sands' most moderate trails.

bodyText:
This three foot by four foot kiosk panel offers an overview of the moderate Dune Life Nature Trail, as well as relevant safety information. 

In addition to reading the entirety of this panel, we strongly recommend that anyone interested in hiking the Dune Life Nature Trail also reads our Hiking Safety page.
audioDescription: This three foot four foot sign hangs on one side of a three-sided kiosk at the start of the Dune Life Nature Trail. The background of the panel features an aerial view of the trail with the parking lot located at the bottom of the image and distant mountains visible at the top. A dotted line marks the trail as it crosses the scrubby grassland, then ascends into the dunes and makes an irregularly shaped loop on the white dunes. Labels indicate your current position at the kiosk next to the parking lot and also states that the trail includes some up and down. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “Know before you go: Dune Life Nature Trail. Ahead you will climb a steep slope and enter the shifting sands of the dunes. This is your first opportunity to walk on the sand. Keep in mind this trail is for observing plant and animal life. If you want to play in the sand, drive further down the road into the heart of the dunes, near the picnic areas. “NO SHADE. Always wear a hat. Take at least two quarts/liters of water with you. PETS must be on a leash AT ALL TIMES. DO NOT TOUCH ANY STRANGE OBJECTS. Sometimes military planes drop dangerous objects on our dunes. “FROM JUNE TO AUGUST, Do not hike in the hottest part of the day. KNOW WHAT TIME THE SUN SETS TODAY. Follow the trail markers. If you can’t see the next marker turn back. Don’t rely on your footprints. They can disappear quickly.” The trail is a one mile loop (1.6 km) and takes about one hour to complete.

title: Dune Life Nature Trail Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many vault toilets at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: Restroom at Dune Life Nature Trail
images.title: Dune Life Nature Trail Restroom
images.caption: The restroom at Dune Life Nature Trail is about a quarter mile from the trailhead.

bodyText: The Dune Life Nature Trail restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, a trash bin, and is adjacent to a parking area with plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs. There are accessible parking spaces directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is next to a gravel road and round parking lot. Facing the doors, visitors can see a large section of grasses with densely vegetated dunes in the background. The doors of the restroom face the Playa Trail and the two-lane road called Dunes Drive.

title: EKO Stop 2 Friends of Katie the Kit Fox

images.altText: A kit fox with a fur pattern of black on top, red on its sides, and white on its belly.
images.title: A Kit Fox
images.caption: A kit fox hanging out in an interdune area.

bodyText: The kit fox is nocturnal, but they are known to come out on cloudy days from time to time. During the day, they stay in their dens to keep out of the heat. A kit fox will grow up to 20 inches (6 crayons) in length and weigh around five pounds. They have hair between their toes which helps them get more traction on the sand. This adaptation helps them to move fast and catch their prey. In the desert, there is very little access to running water. The kit fox gets all the moisture it needs from the food it eats instead of drinking. While it prefers small mammals such as mice, the kit fox will also eat lizards.
audioDescription: A 9 foot tall plant-pedestal made of hardened white sand towers over the trail with multiple plants fixed to the top. Various brown roots pop out of the side, and the wind has blown a trench around about half the structure.

title: End of Pavement
listingDescription: This is the location where the pavement ends and turns to hard-packed gypsum sand.

images.altText: The pavement's end on Dunes Drive.
images.title: End of Pavement
images.caption: The pavement ends a little over halfway along Dunes Drive.

bodyText:
This spot marks Dunes Drive's transition between pavement and hard-packed gypsum sand.

The first five miles of Dunes Drive are paved, and the last three miles are firm sand. The entirety of the road is suitable for cars, motorcycles, recreational vehicles, and buses.
audioDescription: A dark grey, paved road begins to transition into hard-packed, white, gypsum sand. The road is surrounded by small walls of sand that have been displaced by snow plows that maintain the road. Just past the end of the pavement is a cautionary sign warning visitors to take care while driving on the sand. The sign itself has a dark red band on top with text that says: "You are now driving on sand." Placed over an image of the road with the hood of a red car at the bottom is text that reads: "Watch out for machines, people, weather." There are 3 smaller images depicting a tractor, two individuals on bicycles, and a picnic table during white-out conditions above each piece of text.

quickFacts.value: About 4 miles from the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Evening Program Area Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many restrooms in White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Evening Program Area restroom along Dunes Drive.
images.title: Evening Program Area Restroom
images.caption: The Evening Program Area restroom is located in a pullout area along Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The Evening Program Area restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, and a trash bin. It is within a pullout along Dunes Drive with plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs, and there are accessible parking spaces directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is next to a gypsum sand two-lane road called Dunes Drive. The doors face rolling white dunes with vegetation scattered throughout, while behind the building is a large white dune with minimal vegetation.

title: Evolution of the Apache Pocket Mouse - EKO Stop 6

images.altText: Apache pocket mouse with a slightly cream color on top by a green sprout.
images.title: Apache pocket mouse
images.caption: Apache pocket mouse relaxing in the sun by a green sprout growing.

bodyText: They use these pockets to carry food to their dens. Pocket mice will store seeds in their burrows to eat later. If there aren’t enough seeds around, they will also eat leaves, stems of plants, and small insects. The white coloration of the Apache pocket mouse makes it hard for predators to see them. The more a mouse blends in with its habitat, the more likely it will live a long life. With each life cycle, the mice will become lighter because of the process of natural selection. In other words, the lighter mice will survive long enough to reproduce. They spend most of the day under the ground to keep out of the heat of the day. They will block up the den opening during the day to keep the cool night air inside. The tracks of the Apache pocket mouse resemble the movement of when you pretended to be a frog by putting your hands in between your feet on the ground and hop forward.
audioDescription: This section of the trail is very open. Above on top of the hill to the left are some Hoary Rosemary Mint bushes and Soaptree Yuccas. Below on the right, there are a variety of grasses. The grasses in the fall will be a pale tan, but others will have a reddish hue. During the spring and summer these grasses will be green and have various sizes depending on the grass. Little bluestem the grass that turns red will be the tallest. The mice love to run from the hill down into the grass to gather seeds.

title: Evolution of the Bleached Earless Lizard - EKO Stop 4

images.altText: Bleached earless lizard basking in the sun is surrounded by white sand.
images.title: Bleached Earless Lizard
images.caption: Bleached earless lizard basking in the sun is surrounded by white sand.

bodyText:
Darker lizards are easy for predators to see. While lighter lizards can hide against the gypsum sand, helping them hide. Lizards that escape getting caught due to their white color live longer. If you live longer, you will have more offspring. Their babies will inherit the bright white color and then, in time, pass the coloration onto their own offspring.

You can sometimes see them running around the dunes catching bugs. The lizards talk to each other by bobbing their heads, just like you have probably seen other kinds of lizards do. They do have ears, but they are not visible like ours. The ears have a layer of skin that helps keep the sand out while digging.
audioDescription: This area is very open and mostly sandy with a few plant pedestals. The lizards like this area because they can sunbathe in the flat sand. Past the openness are a few plants that they tend to retreat to during the hottest part of the day.

title: Extended Family
listingDescription: This interpretive sign describes White Sands and its sister park, the Área de Protección de Flora y Fauna Cuatrociénegas.

images.altText: Interpretive sign the explains the relationship between White Sands and its' sister park.
images.title: Extended Family
images.caption: Working together can help prevent future impacts to the dunefield.

bodyText: While White Sands might be the largest gypsum dunefield in the world it is not the only. Partnering with Área de Protección de Flora y Fauna Cuatrociénegas allows the park to study impacts on gypsum dunes and how the dunefields respond.
audioDescription: This three one half foot by one foot sign is mounted on the platform railing at the end of the boardwalk. The background of the panel shows a map of the southern United States and northern Mexico. A brown area marking the Chihuahuan Desert extends from central Mexico up to southern New Mexico where White Sands is and just over into southeast Arizona. An inset image shows White Sands viewed from space, an area 19 miles across. At the southern end of the desert is Cuatrociénegas with a satellite view showing a white area three miles across. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “Families today often reach across cities, states, even continents. White Sands National Monument and Área de Protección de Flora y Fauna Cuatrociénegas, in Mexico, are sister parks. They work together to preserve two of the largest gypsum dunefields in the world. “Área de Protección de Flora y Fauna Cuatrociénegas – This unique 325-square-mile desert wetland preserves a 250-acre dunefield and many rare features, including a lizard found nowhere else in the world.” A small picture at bottom left shows a lizard with brown skin circled by bands of white edged in black. The caption identifies this as Lugo’s alligator lizard, Gerrhonotus lugoi. On the right side of the panel is a row of pictures of men and women, most wearing some type of uniform, from South Korea, Ghana, Australia, Mexico, Congo, Germany and Guatemala. Text reads, “National Parks Around the World. The idea to create national parks was born in the United States in 1872. It has grown into an international family. Nearly half the countries in the world now have national parks. Australia has the most—almost 700.”

title: Eye Spy with My Little Eye

images.altText: A white dune slopes toward the vegetation of the desert floor with a mountain range in the distance.
images.title: A Vast Space
images.caption: As far as the eye can see, the dunes stretch to meet the mountains and the setting sun.

bodyText: The unique environment here is home to over 800 species of plants and animals. Of those, over 650 are moths! Moths are important pollinators for the plants of the dunefield and great snacks for the birds and bats. Imagine being a bird or a bat migrating and coming across this island feast!
audioDescription: This sign, about 2 feet wide and one and one-half feet high, is mounted at an angle on a single metal post. The sign sits near the top of a smooth sand dune, which extends even higher slightly to your left. Directly past the sign is a small clump of scrubby cottonwood trees, looking like large bushes. Behind you and to the right, the sand slopes downward to the grass covered basin floor below. The trail continues to your right and slightly downward as it rounds the shoulder of the big dune you are standing on. The sign has a picture of Katie, the cartoon fox figure, in the upper left, with text in both English and Spanish along the top. The bottom part of the sign has a picture of a bobcat, crouched down as it slinks towards us. It has light brown, dappled fur and amber eyes. In the lower left of the sign is a picture of a Black-tailed Jackrabbit sitting with its long ears laid down along its back, its wide eyes staring off to the left. Text at the top reads, “Do you like to eat the same food, night after night? Not me! I like to eat a lot of different things. The bobcats that also live here in the dunes like to eat jackrabbits—a lot! Biologists who study desert bobcats say that 45% of their diet comes from just one prey: jackrabbits! It takes a lot of 4-pound rabbits to keep a 24-pound bobcat going strong.” End of description.

title: Final Stop of Backcountry Tour
listingDescription: As you wrap up your journey, this is a great place to stop, hydrate, and appreciate the view.

images.altText: A large shrub at sunset on the Backcountry Camping Loop Trail.
images.title: Backcountry Sunset
images.caption: Various plants await you on the Backcountry Loop Trail.

bodyText:
We’ve reached the end of the Backcountry Camping Loop Trail self-guided tour. At this stop, feel free to climb to the top of the tallest dune near to you and soak up the view. What can you see? Maybe you’re watching the sun set behind the mountains, or maybe you’ve got sled in hand and are just beginning your adventures.

Whether you’re just starting your day or are heading home, the time you spend here will stay with you forever. With your help, and by continuing to recreate responsibly on your public lands, these wild spaces will be around forever, too.

Take as much time as you’d like to enjoy the view. When you’re done, you can either follow the trail back towards the trailhead, or explore another part of the Backcountry Camping Loop.
audioDescription: The visitor is surrounded by white dunes rising and falling on all sides, with distant mountains visible both to the west and the east. The dunes are bare white sand, often with ripples across their surface. In between are small flat basins with some clumps of grass, small bushes and an occasional yucca plant. At this location the visitor is on top of the tallest nearby dune, looking out into the vast white dunefield.

quickFacts.value: Near the wooden marker for campsite 10
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Final Stop on our Auto Self Guided Tour

images.altText: White sand dunes with mountains in the distance at sunset
images.title: Sunset at White Sands
images.caption: We hope you've enjoyed your day at White Sands and visit again soon

bodyText: Congrats on completing this self-guided audio tour! At the final stop here at the Backcountry Camping Loop take a minute to climb into the dunes near the parking lot and gaze out into the rolling white dunes. Whether you’re just beginning your day here at White Sands or finishing it with a breathtaking sunset you’ve gone on a journey that shows what makes White Sands a special place worthy of being protected as a National Park. You have seen the raw natural forces that have built this place over millions of years and the adaptability of life to survive in an everchanging environment. You have walked in the footsteps of ice age humans and mammoths as well as Mars rovers exploring the solar system. Take time to reflect here on this place, your visit, and what will be remembered about your day here. Thank you for supporting the National Park Service and recreating responsibly on your public lands to keep these spaces wild and pristine.
audioDescription: This trail begins at a parking area at the side of the road. Near the start of the trail the parking area is edged with a split-rail fence. In front of the fence is a tall, three-sided kiosk with three graphic panels. To the right of the kiosk as you face the trail is a picnic shelter and table. At the far side of the parking area is a small restroom building. Near the beginning of the trail is a small sign that reads, “Parking for Backcountry Camping. Permit required. Available at Visitor Center.”

title: First Stop of Backcountry Camping Loop Trail Tour
listingDescription: Come along as we explore some of the ways human use of the world's largest gypsum sand dunefield has changed over the last century.

images.altText: A grainy, black and white photo of visitors on the dunes at White Sands.
images.title: White Sands Visitors (1904)
images.caption: This photo, from 1904, shows hikers from around 30 years before the Monument's establishment.

bodyText:
Welcome to White Sands National Park’s digital self-guided tour! If you see the Backcountry Camping Loop Trailhead in front of you, you’re in the right place.

White Sands is far more than just a sandbox. Over time, this land has been home to countless creatures and people. It’s been a site for research and recreation, sleds and snapshots. Just as the landscape shifts and changes every day, the way recent humans have utilized this place has changed, too. As we begin our voyage to explore how the ways we use this landscape has changed over time, remember that nothing is permanent – especially not the world’s largest gypsum sand dunes. Keep in mind that you may need to adjust your location to get a better view along the way.

Here are a few more tips to help you make the most of this self-led tour:

  • Read up on our hiking safety tips before setting off on foot.

  • Bring plenty of water! We strongly recommend having at least a gallon of water per person, per day. There is no drinking water available in the dunefield.

  • Always know where you are, and keep a keen eye on the trail markers both behind you and ahead of you. The backcountry trail markers will all have the spade symbol on them.

  • Please be respectful of visitors setting up camp at the designated sites along the trail, and try to avoid wandering into campsites uninvited. We’re not Goldilocks, and the beds probably won’t fit “just right.”

Now if you’re ready to begin, you can continue along the trail. 

Let’s go!
audioDescription: This trail begins at a parking area at the side of the road. Near the start of the trail the parking area is edged with a split-rail fence. In front of the fence is a tall, three-sided kiosk with three graphic panels. To the right of the kiosk as you face the trail is a picnic shelter and table. At the far side of the parking area is a small restroom building. Near the beginning of the trail is a small sign that reads, “Parking for Backcountry Camping. Permit required. Available at Visitor Center.”

title: Fuzzy Plants - EKO Stop 3

images.altText: Pale green hoary rosemary mint grows out of the white gypsum sand
images.title: Hoary Rosemary Mint
images.caption: Pale green Hoary Rosemary Mint

bodyText: The wind moves the sand around at White Sands National Park. Many plants can’t grow inside the sand because they will blow away in the wind. The plants that grow in the sand have all found different ways to survive here. A plant pedestal is one such way of surviving. It is a tall structure of hardened sand. Pedestals form when the plant takes up water from the soil. When the soil dries out, the sand will compact around the root system. The wind blows the loose sand away from the root system, exposing the pedestal underneath. Hoary rosemary mint leaves have shiny white hairs all over. The hairs help protect the plant from the sun. Just like when we put on sunscreen, it protects us from getting burnt.
audioDescription: On the right side of this section of the trail, you will find many hoary rosemary mint bushes. They are soft to the touch and make your hands smell like rosemary and mint put together. The undergrowth contains dead branches making the plants base seem rougher. When in bloom, the flowers will be a light lavender color with three petals fused together. The plant itself is a pale minty green color but during the winter it will not be as vibrant in color and half less leaves.

title: Gone with the Wind

images.altText: Rippled white sand dune with wind blowing over the crest of the dune. Half the dune is in shadow.
images.title: Windy Dune
images.caption: Any wind over 17 mph picks up the sand and causes the dunes movement eastward

bodyText: As you gaze out your window you should see the sign “Gone With the Wind,” and beyond that sparse vegetation, and pure white dunes. How far do you think you can see? On most days you can see for miles, including the surrounding mountain ranges. Now I want you to imagine those mountains becoming obscured. A windstorm has picked up. You can feel it beating against the side of your car. It’s howling all around you. As the wind increases, visibility decreases. You can see a mile away. Then 500 feet. The yucca on the next dune is no longer visible. Then 100 feet. You can no longer see the sledding family. Then 20 feet. Then 5 feet in front of you. You are in the middle of white-out blizzard conditions, but instead of snow, it’s gypsum sand. If you were to try to leave your vehicle, assuming you could get the door open, the result would not be pleasant, gypsum would sandblast its way into every nook and cranny, the feeling of thousands of tiny needles against your skin. Moving only a few feet away from your vehicle could result in total disorientation. Now, what are some words you would use to describe our theoretical encounter? (pause) Wild? Dangerous? Perhaps even violent? As humans, we ascribe violence to nature quite often. Violent storms, volcanoes, and floods are found throughout most of the world. All these forces we may fear or try to prevent, help create the stunning landscapes and natural beauty we love – and the environment you are currently looking at. Eventually, the windstorm subsides, revealing pristine dunes, no footprints insight, with patterns of ripples coating its surface. Dunes move to new destinations, covering plants and revealing fresh ground for others to grow. Seeds fly to those new homes. From the beginning to now, without wind, this landscape would not exist. To change selenite, the crystal form of gypsum, to sand, the wind erodes the landscape. Crystals bounce off each other, collide, and break into smaller and smaller pieces, until they’re the size of a grain of sand, piling high to form the dunes you are seeing. Even though the dunefield loses sand during these windstorms, the wind also carries in new sand, keeping the dunefield in balance.
audioDescription: From the pull-off, there is an interpretive metal sign which says " " and describes how the wind builds the dunes here in the park. Across the park road there is a larger parking area which goes right up to a 20 foot tall dune. In all directions the white sand dunes are expansive, range from 20-40 feet, and have very little vegetation mixed in the further you drive on the park road.

title: Gone with the Wind Roadside Exhibit
listingDescription: This is one of several waysides along Dunes Drive at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The "Gone with the Wind" wayside, located along Dunes Drive.
images.title: "Gone with the Wind" Wayside
images.caption: The "Gone with the Wind" wayside is located along Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The "Gone with the Wind" wayside, located along Dunes Drive, describes the impermanence and ever-shifting nature of White Sands National Park.
audioDescription: This 4-foot by 2-foot sign is mounted two wooden posts in a wide parking area next to the road. Both the parking lot and the road are hard-packed sand. The dunes surround you are pure white and stand close to 20 feet high. The only vegetation visible is in a flat basin on the other side of the sign. The background of the panel features a satellite image of the region, with a broad band of white stretching out between the two mountain ranges. The area of the park is outline in green at the lower left of the white. Red arrows point from left to right. Text reads, “Strong winds can blow gypsum dust for hundreds of miles. But without the wind, there would be no dunes to enjoy.” There are three other photographs on the panel, all in black and white, one on the left and two on the right. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “In this land of constant motion, nothing is permanent. Everything here moves—or we can move it. Any strong windstorm can wipe out this road in a matter of hours. Our 20-year-veteran heavy equipment operator once said, “If I spent all my time, 40 hours a week out there, it wasn’t enough time to do the roads…” The photograph on the left shows a road plow, scraping back sand at the base of a white slope. The caption reads, “Roadwork here never ends.” Near the right side of the panel another photograph shows a flat trail marker in the middle of the dunes with only about a foot sticking up out of the sand. The caption reads, “Trails: here today, gone tomorrow.” The picture at the far right shows a picnic table with a slatted awning that rises from one bench to curve up and overhead. The caption reads, “Even our picnic shelters are moveable.”

title: Group Use Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many restrooms at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The group use area restroom, which is located in a reservable area designed for large groups.
images.title: Group Use Restroom
images.caption: The group use area has one restroom near the entrance of the parking lot.

bodyText: The group use restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, and trash bins. It is adjacent to the group use picnic area, which is accessible by vehicle when the area is reserved in advance. There is plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs in the group use lot, and there are accessible places to park directly in front of the restroom.

There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is in a large gypsum sand parking lot. The building is surrounded by rolling white dunes with sparse vegetation scattered throughout, with many picnic tables lined up in rows behind it.

title: Heart of the Sands Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many restrooms at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Heart of the Sands restroom along Dunes Drive.
images.title: Heart of the Sands Restroom
images.caption: The Heart of the Sands restroom is located just before the Primrose and Roadrunner Picnic Areas.

bodyText: The Heart of the Sands restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, and trash bins. It is within a parking area along Dunes Drive with space to park automobiles and RVs, and there are accessible areas to park directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is next to a gypsum sand two-lane road called Dunes Drive. The doors face a small, round gypsum sand parking lot. Behind the building is Dunes Drive, with rolling white dunes throughout.

title: Horse Unloading Area
listingDescription: This is where visitors looking to bring horses or other pack animals into the park are able to park trailers and unload their animals.

images.altText: A large parking area surrounded by white gypsum sand dunes.
images.title: Horse Unloading Area
images.caption: The Horse Unloading Area at sunset.

bodyText:
The Horse Unloading Area is a large parking lot. It is the only area vehicles towing horse trailers are allowed to park and unload, but it accommodates vehicles without trailers, as well. 

Besides being a great place to park large trailers, many visitors also enjoy parking in this lot and sledding. For more information about bringing horses into the park, visit the Horses and Other Pack Animals page on our website.
audioDescription: The Horse Unloading Area is a large, gypsum sand parking lot surrounded by rolling white dunes. There is sparse vegetation scattered throughout, including soaptree yuccas and various plants and grasses. There are two signs in the Horse Unloading Area, and both are bordered by simple wooden fences. The first sign is small, dark brown, and rectangular, with white text that reads: Horse Trailer Unloading. It has a block drawing of a stick figure riding a horse and a camping trailer underneath the text. The second sign is larger, and is also dark brown and rectangular. It has a horizontal bar at the top, filled with a drawing of eight riders on horses traversing across the dunefield, with the mountain range as a backdrop. The white text below this image is separated by thin white lines, and reads: Before You Ride. Register at the entrance station. Stop for all hikers. Let them pass. Always keep your horse under physical control. Don't ride horses on roads or trails. Clean up manure.

quickFacts.value: About 7 miles from the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Imagine All This Sand... Gone
listingDescription: This interpretive sign showcases the potential monetary value of White Sands National Park.

images.altText: Interpretive sign explains some of the products gypsum can be found in.
images.title: Imagine All This Sand... Gone
images.caption: Finding value in the sand around you.

bodyText: Everything around you has value, including white gypsum sand. Gypsum is used in the food you eat as well as sheetrock that frames walls in houses. Finding a monetary value in the sand is one of the main reasons protections for the dunefield was originally sought for.
audioDescription: This three and one half foot by one foot sign is mounted on the platform railing at the end of the boardwalk. The background of the panel shows the white sand dunes with a front-end loader at the left side, its scoop full of sand. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “Years ago, some people looked at these shifting dunes and saw dollar signs—millions of them. Here were endless tons of potential profit, lying loose on the ground, so easy to scoop up and haul off.” In the middle of the panel is a black and white photograph of a man and a woman identified as Tom and Bula Charles. Next to that photo is a picture of an old sign reading “Visit the heart of the White Sands National Monument, educational and recreational, United States National Park Service.” Text reads, “Bring Tourists, not Tractors. Beginning in 1885, curious geologists studied these white sands. People long debated its economic value versus its natural significance. Alamogordo businessman Thomas Charles led the effort in the 1920s to make this a national park rather than an enormous mine.” On the right end of the panel are pictures of a variety of products including dry wall boards, bread, ice cream, toothpaste, wine and beer, cheese and a bandaged hand. Text reads, “Why is gypsum so valuable today? Gypsum is a $100-million-a-year industry. It is the main ingredient in drywall and plaster of Paris. Did you know this mineral is found in all kinds of food, household products, and medicines? Fact: During your lifetime you will eat an average of 28 pounds of gypsum.”

title: In the Shadow of Trinity

images.altText: A black and white photo of an explosion and fireball shooting upwards in a dome
images.title: Trinity Fireball
images.caption: The Trinity Test took place approximately 60 miles north of White Sands National Park

bodyText: What is the day that has most impacted your life? Is it a major event like a wedding? A birth? A death? Or was it a leisurely day like today exploring in a park like this? Why did this one day have a long-lasting impact on your life? These special days that change our lives are unique for each one of us but we all undoubtedly have them. Even rarer than a day that has a special significance to just you, are days that have an undeniable impact on every person on earth. If you had been standing here in the early morning of July 16<sup>th</sup>, 1945, you would have been witness to such an event. As you look out over the dunes to the north, imagine you are here before sunrise and a blinding flash of light appears in the distance before fading away without explanation. The first shot of the atomic age had been fired 60 miles to the north at the Trinity Test site. For three years in near-total secrecy scientists and workers at three sites across the United States had been developing a new kind of weapon designed to bring a swift end to World War II. Known collectively as the Manhattan Project, the Trinity Test was the culmination of their years of work and within weeks of the successful test here in New Mexico the first atomic weapons would be dropped at Hiroshima and Nagasaki, avoiding a full-scale invasion of Japan, but inflicting hundreds of thousands in civilian casualties. To this day they are the only nuclear weapons to have been used. However, the opening of the nuclear age at the Trinity site has had untold impacts on the world we live in. The potential for nuclear weapons to end human existence through mutually assured destruction has dominated global politics throughout the Cold War and into the 21<sup>st</sup> century. It has brought benefits to society in the forms of nuclear energy and medicine, but the adverse impacts cannot be ignored. In communities downwind from nuclear testing sites or uranium mines, the consequences have been devastating with high rates of cancer and birth defects. The Trinity Test is the point in time when the Pandora’s box of the atomic age was opened, and these sands bore witness to that moment.
audioDescription: From the parking area, white sand dunes that vary from 10 to 40 feet expand in all directions on both sides of the road with sparse vegetation dotting the landscape. On both ends of the parking area there are brown, metal signs which say "Sunset Stroll Starts Here" with a time posted under it to indicate when the evening sunset nature walk program leaves from this parking lot every night. In the distance to the east and west are the Sacramento and San Andres Mountains towering above the relatively flat expanse of the Tularosa Basin below

title: Interdune Boardwalk
listingDescription: This is the only wheelchair-accessible trail at White Sands National Park, and offers a variety of interpretive signs that showcase many of the incredible creatures and features found at White Sands.

images.altText: A visitor walking down the Interdune Boardwalk.
images.title: Interdune Boardwalk
images.caption: Being a boardwalk above the sand, this trail is perfect for everyone.

bodyText:
The Interdune Boardwalk is fully accessible for people using wheelchairs and strollers. Take an easy 0.4 mile (650m) round trip stroll through the dunes and learn about the science, geology, plants, and animals that make White Sands an unequaled natural wonder. The boardwalk is a great place to take a break under the shade canopy, listen for bird calls, observe lizards, and enjoy wildflowers. The average completion time is 20 minutes.

Length: 0.4 mile (650m), round-trip
Average Completion Time: 20 minutes
Difficulty: Easy
Distance from Visitor Center: 4.5 miles (7.2 km)
Restroom: Two vault toilets at the trailhead

Before setting out on foot at White Sands National Park, please view our Hiking Safety Tips.
audioDescription: The parking lot at this trail is a large rectangular area of hard-packed white sand. The side of the area away from the road is bordered by a split-rail fence. The entrance to the trail is near the left end of the fence. The walkway is five feet wide and made of wooden planks painted grey with a roughened surface. There are recycled plastic railings on both sides. A vertical board at the bottom of the side rails clearly marks the edge of the walk. A metal grill leads up at a slight angle from the ground to the beginning of the walkway. A sign at the entrance to the walk warns that the boardwalk is slippery when frosty or wet. The walk makes a gentle zig-zag about four-tenths of a mile into a sandy area between two low dune ridges. On either side of the walk are patches of vegetation, with low bushes and spikey yucca plants. At several spots along the walk it widens to make room for a bench. The far end is a 15 by 20-foot platform. About half way down the walk, a side walk on the right leads to another 15 by 20-foot platform, this one covered by a tent canopy with three rows of benches on either side of a center aisle. Attached to the railings of both platforms are multiple wayside graphic panels. Along the fence at the right side of the walk entrance is a tall, three-sided kiosk with more signs.

title: Interdune Boardwalk Kiosk Panel

images.altText: The Interdune Boardwalk kiosk panel just before sunset.
images.title: Interdune Boardwalk Kiosk Panel
images.caption: The Interdune Boardwalk kiosk panel features a bleached earless lizard.

title: Interdune Boardwalk Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many vault toilets at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The restroom at the Interdune Boardwalk.
images.title: Interdune Boardwalk Restroom
images.caption: This restroom is located just off of Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The Interdune Boardwalk restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, a trash bin, and is adjacent to a parking area with plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is next to a paved two-lane road called Dunes Drive. The doors face the Interdune Boardwalk trailhead. When facing the doors, visitors can see large white dunes surrounding them with some vegetation scattered throughout.

title: Interdune Boardwalk Safety Kiosk Panel
listingDescription: This is one of several important safety panels located at White Sands National Park, and offers potentially life-saving information.

images.altText: The safety kiosk panel located at the Interdune Boardwalk.
images.title: Interdune Boardwalk Safety Panel
images.caption: This is one of several important safety panels found within White Sands National Park.

bodyText: This is one of several safety information panels found at White Sands National Park. We strongly encourage visitors hiking at White Sands to read these panels before beginning any on-foot adventures.

title: Let’s Solve a Mystery!

images.altText: A sign and blue trail marker sit amongst tall green grass that give way to white dunes with shrubs.
images.title: Trailhead of Dune Life Nature Trail
images.caption: Where the dunes meet the desert, plants, and animals flourish.

bodyText:
Welcome to White Sands National Park! You’ll be journeying along one of the park’s marked trails today to learn about the dunefield through your senses. Here are a few more tips to help you make the most of this self-led tour:

  • Read up on our hiking safety tips before setting off on foot.

  • Bring plenty of water! We recommend having a gallon of water per person, per day. There is no drinking water available in the dunefield.

  • Always know where you are and keep an eye on the trail markers both behind you and ahead of you. Dune Life Nature Trail’s markers are blue with the club symbol.

Let’s go!
audioDescription: From the parking lot, the hard-packed dirt trail leads through the split-rail fence, past a three-sided kiosk with informational signs, and then across flat grassland to the white dunes. The trail then ascends up the sand between two dunes to a wayside sign, where the loop trail then splits to the left and the right. The trail is marked by flat, four-inch wide, blue posts marked with a three-leaved clover symbol. The trail meanders up and down the dunes, which are dotted with a variety of grasses, bushes, and the occasional small tree. The footing varies from hard-packed dirt to soft sand. The parking lot is a loop and is adjacent to the vault toilets. At the beginning of the trail near the parking lot, a brown sign reads, “Dune Life Nature Trail. This one-mile loop trail winds through the edge of the white sands, where dune life is most abundant. Watch for the tracks left behind by various desert animals as they hunt for food among the dunes. Two steep climbs will be encountered on this walk. Summer temperatures can exceed 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Take plenty of water and protect your skin from the sun. Please lock your car.” Further down the trail, another sign warns, “Stop – Stay Alive. Water is required for this trail. Take 64 ounces or two liters of water for each person in your group. When your water is half gone, return to your car. Warning Dangerous to hike above 85 degrees Fahrenheit.” End of description.

title: Life Thrives Roadside Exhibit
listingDescription: This is one of several interpretive waysides along Dunes Drive at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The "Life Thrives" wayside, located along Dunes Drive.
images.title: "Life Thrives" Wayside
images.caption: The "Life Thrives" wayside is located along Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The "Life Thrives" wayside, located along Dunes Drive, highlights the fragile microscopic life found in the dunefield.
audioDescription: This four foot by two foot sign stands in a metal frame at the edge of a pullout along the road that winds its way into the heart of the dunes. The land on this side of the road is more of the flat, scrub-covered desert land. To your left as you face the sign is a low ridge of dunes, which the road skirts on the left and then disappears behind as it curves back to the right. On the other side of the road is a narrow strip of brush-covered land backed by low dunes. The top half of the panel features an aerial view of this area showing Dunes Drive winding its way from the highway at the right into the heart of the dunes at the left, where it makes a loop. A label marks your current location about midway along the road. Labels at the top identify the changing landscape from the brown-colored Chihuahuan desert at the right, through a changing innerdunal zone, where the brown shows streaks of white, into the heart of the dunes which is totally white. Across the middle of the panel is text in both English and Spanish that reads, “In between the dunes is where life thrives. But just your footsteps can kill the microscopic life in this crust soil. It takes years to regrow.” The bottom part of the panel shows a bird’s eye view looking past the road over the pure white dunes to the mountains in the distance. Again, a label marks your current location near the end of a finger of brown desert that reaches up towards the white dunes. Every patch of brown on the image has a symbol of a footstep with a red line drawn through it. More text asks us to “Stay on bare sand as you walk.”

title: Lift the Land
listingDescription: This interpretive sign highlights some of the geologic processes that created White Sands National Park.

images.altText: Interpretive sign explains the formation of the land in the Tularosa Basin.
images.title: Lift the Land
images.caption: The land you are standing on formed millions of years ago.

bodyText: What keeps all the sand here? Formation of the land millions of years ago not only formed the land in a way that creates dunes but also in a way that keeps all the sand here.
audioDescription: This three and one half foot by one foot sign is mounted on the platform railing at the end of the boardwalk. On the right side of the panel, the background shows a picture of the Sacramento Mountains. White horizontal layers of gypsum are visible on the mountain sides. On the left side of the panel are illustrations showing movement of the earth’s crust. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “The Making of White Sands, Stage 2. Powerful forces from deep under the Earth changed everything you see around you. Some places rose, then separated. Once-buried layers of gypsum came back into view.” At the left side of the panel is a cutaway drawing of the earth’s crust showing one plate moving in from the west and sliding under another plate. Text reads, “PLATES COLLIDE, one forced under, the other up.” Next to the drawing is a map from 70 million years ago that shows the land in Arizona and New Mexico moving upwards as land under the Pacific Ocean slides underneath. To the right of that, another cutaway drawing shows a mountain being split apart as the two sides move outwards, leaving an opening in between. Text reads, “RIFT IN THE CRUST pulling apart mountains, leaving openings called basins.” To the right of that is a map from 30 million years ago showing the Rocky Mountains splitting into the Rio Grande Rift with White Sands located near the southern end of the spreading crust.

title: Moth Tour - Why are Moths Important?

images.altText: Light yellow moth with dark markings on white background
images.title: Eucosma metzleri
images.caption: A pale yellow moth known as Eucosma metzleri, a moth named after the park’s moth researcher.

bodyText:
White Sands National Park presents a unique opportunity to learn more how life evolves and adapts to harsh and unique environments. Since 2007, Eric Metzler, an expert entomologist and volunteer at White Sands, has discovered over 650 different species of moths in these dunes. Sixty of those species are entirely new to science.
.
This moth research is critical because moths are a great indicator of a ecosystems health. The greater the diversity of moths, the greater the diversity of other animal and plant species, therefore the healthier the ecosystem! If moths died out, songbirds would all but disappear.
audioDescription: The entrance to the trail is near the left end of the fence. The walkway is five feet wide and made of planks painted grey with a roughened surface. There are recycled plastic railings on both sides. A vertical board at the bottom of the side rails clearly marks the edge of the walk. A metal grill leads up at a slight angle from the ground to the beginning of the walkway. A sign at the entrance to the walk warns that the boardwalk is slippery when frosty or wet.

title: Moths, Mars, and Lizards
listingDescription: This interpretive sign highlights some of the research being done at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: Interpretive sign explaining the unique research being done at the park.
images.title: Moths, Mars, and Lizards
images.caption: With research comes once in a lifetime discoveries.

bodyText: What do moths, mars, and lizards all have in common? All three of them are heavily researched at White Sands. Researchers from all over the globe come to the park to study the uniques environment and the animals within.
audioDescription: This 3 and 1/2 foot by 1 foot sign is mounted on the railing under the tent shelter along the boardwalk. The background picture shows a reddish landscape of sand and gravel with several lumpy mounds scattered about. Text tells us that these crystal pedestals are similar to those found on Mars. At the top of the panel is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “What on Earth (or off) do these things have in common? They are all examples of wild science happening here and now at White Sands.” More text at the left reads, “Moths Apparently Love White Sands. Researchers identified over 650 species of moths in just a 2-mile radius (1%) of the park. Thirty five of those species were brand new, found only in White Sands.” Below that text are two photographs of moths, one with wings outstretched, the other with wings folded back. Both are white, with pale grey or tan markings. In the middle text reads, “Sister Dunes. In 2004 Mars Rover Opportunity landed on a playa made up of gypsum, just like you see here at White Sands. By studying our dunes, NASA scientists are learning more about the red planet—and possibly the future of White Sands.” Below the text are two photographs. One shows four people examining a sand pedestal. The other is a 2013 picture of the Mars Curiosity rover on the surface of Mars. More text at the right side of the panel reads, “Hotbed of Evolution. Here you can see many animals that have changed color radically to boost their chances to survive. We know these dunes have only been here for 10,000 years. White Sands gives us a chance to see evolution happening before our eyes.” Below are photographs of three pure white creatures. One looks like a type of grasshopper. The middle one looks like a type of beetle. The one on the right shows a white lizard.

title: Mystery Solved!

images.altText: An aerial photo of white dunes with shadows and plants growing on them.
images.title: Everything the Light Touches
images.caption: Shadows play across the dunefield, creating contrast and signaling sunrise.

bodyText: Here at the edge of the dunefield, where the dunes meet the Chihuahuan desert, plants and animals thrive! The dramatic change from dunes to desert floor occurs because the water table that holds the dunes in place disappears. But don’t worry, plenty of animals and plants call the desert home. As you visit other natural and unique spaces, remember to engage all your senses to fully appreciate your surroundings. Stay safe and keep exploring!
audioDescription: The trail continues across the width of the ridge to the two large pedestals which mark the place that the trail ascends from the parking lot below, and the beginning of this loop trail through the dunes. Pedestals are outcroppings of solid sand about 12 feet high, topped with thick vegetation. Their vertical surfaces are made of hardened sand with many cracks and uneven places where chunks of sand have fallen off, looking like miniature cliff faces.

title: Nature Scavenger Hunt - EKO Stop 1

images.altText: A kid leaves footprints in the sand on a partly cloudy day.
images.title: Footprints on a Cloudy Day
images.caption: A kid leaves footprints in the sand on a partly cloudy day.

bodyText: Continue straight on the desert trail with vegetation on both sides and up the first dune. Once the path becomes loose sand and splits, walk up the white dune onto the trailhead. The informational signs of the trail in the dunes go clockwise. At the first trail sign about “Who Eats What” follow the trail markers to the left of the informational sign.
audioDescription: From the parking lot, the hard-packed dirt trail leads through the split-rail fence, past a three-sided kiosk with informational signs.

title: Park Closures
listingDescription: When military tests are in progress Dunes Drive is closed to all traffic.

images.altText: Sign for park closures and missile test in progress.
images.title: Park Clourse
images.caption: When military tests are in progress Dunes Drive is closed to all traffic.

bodyText:
White Sands Missile Range regularly conducts missile tests. For visitor safety, the only road into the dunefield, Dunes Drive, may be closed for periods of up to three hours during missile tests. Park staff is usually notified two weeks in advance of scheduled tests; however, notifications from White Sands Missile Range may be received up to 24 hours in advance of a test. Park staff work to inform the public as far in advance as possible for upcoming tests and park closures.

Click here to see currently scheduled park closures
