title: Park Store and Gift Shop
listingDescription: Shop in the White Sands park store and the gift shop.

images.altText: Merchandise being sold at the park's store.
images.title: The Park store and Gift Shop
images.caption: Take home a memory from your visit to White Sands National Park

bodyText:
White Sands National Park has partnerships with a variety of organizations in order to help the National Park Service fulfill its mission. Partners provide important support for education, sustainability initiatives, enhanced visitor experiences, management solutions, and park research. The park strives to nurture these collaborations in order to enhance visitor opportunities, and provide experiences that enable visitors to enjoy outdoor recreation and learn about environmental and cultural resources. Two of our key partners, Western National Parks Association and White Sands Trading LLC, operate retail outlets in the park.

 


Western National Parks Association

As a nonprofit education partner of the National Park Service, Western National Parks Association supports 71 national park partners across the West, developing products, services, and programs that enrich the visitor experience.

Missed us on your last visit? No problem, please visit our online store.

Western National Parks Association’s mission, in partnership with the National Park Service since 1938, is to advance education, interpretation, research, and community engagement to ensure national parks are increasingly valued by all.

The Western National Park Store at White Sands National Park is able to directly support the development of products, programs, ongoing research, and the White Sands interpretive mission through your purchases. Each item in the store has been selected and approved for sale by park and Western National Parks Association staff in order to inspire and inform our visitors as well as aiding in the creation of lasting memories.

Shop in the White Sands park store and become a member today. Receive monthly event calendars, quarterly newsletters, 15% discounts off most store purchases and discounts on select Western National Parks Association field trips and workshops. Most importantly, by becoming a member you join a growing team of advocates who are passionate about supporting the mission of our National Parks.

Western National Parks Association is proud to be affiliated with White Sands National Park and to help educate visitors to the diverse history of this unique place. Financial support from Western National Parks Association is used to provide education and interpretive programing including full moon nights and school field trips as well as scientific research on the endemic moths of White Sands.
 


White Sands Trading, LLC

White Sands Trading (WST), official concessioner of White Sands National Park and a New Mexico family-owned company, is proud to join with the National Park Service in preserving this rich ecosystem for generations to come. We are vigilant in using best practices to limit our impact on the environment and to educate visitors about the fragility of this unique area.

Since 2005, the White Sands Trading Gift Shop has been providing visitors with unique mementos of White Sands National Park. We offer authentic Native American handcrafts from New Mexico including intricately detailed pottery and sterling silver jewelry. Visitors of all ages enjoy our sand disks while sledding down the dunes. Our grab-and-go area will satisfy your hunger with sandwiches and snacks. You can also restock your water or chose from a variety of beverages. A varied selection of t-shirts and souvenirs will help you memorialize your visit to the largest gypsum dunefield on earth.

WST pays a franchise fee of 16% of our gross receipts to the park. This money is used to make improvements within the park. We appreciate your support and look forward to continuing our mission of preserving the historic building we occupy while protecting the unparalleled desert-scape of White Sands National Park.

title: Permanent Residents, Temporary Visitors

images.altText: A small, gray and orange fox darts away from a trail camera flash on white sand at night
images.title: Kit Fox on Trail Camera
images.caption: The kit fox is North America's smallest, wild canine and the largest full time resident in the dunes

bodyText: You are currently located at Dune Life Nature Trail! As you look up the trail leading into the dunes you will see desert scrubland vegetation on either side of the trail. Perhaps this is greener than you were expecting to see at a place with a name like White Sands. Here towards the front of the drive is a meeting point of two unique ecosystems that allows a diverse community to thrive. On Dune Life Nature Trail just up the path from the parking lot, you’ll find yourself in another world where snow white dunes are dotted with dune adapted plants such as soaptree yuccas, Rio Grande cottonwoods, and hoary rosemary mint. Across the park road towards the Sacramento Mountains to the east, you will see the Chihuahuan Desert scrubland full of low-growing, thorny fauna such as creosote bush, mesquite, ocotillo, and varieties of cacti. In the dunes, you’ll find full-time residents like kangaroo rats, bleached earless lizards, and over 60 species of moth found nowhere else on earth that have become color adapted to the blindingly white environment. The largest predator that lives full time in the dunes is a kit fox which weighs in at a whopping 4 pounds! Animals residing in the dunes are small, compact, and efficient with their water, never taking a drink in their life. But the White Sands community is more than just what’s found in the dunes. On the edge of the dunefield where the sand meets the desert scrubland, the park receives some interesting visitors. Larger mammals like bobcats, coyotes, badgers, and even porcupines that couldn’t survive in the dunes year-round make their way into the dunes to get the resources they need and then return to their homes in the scrubland. These temporary visitors to the dunes are no less of a part of the dunefield community whether their impact is big or small. Your visit to White Sands today is also a temporary one where you might come to hike, sled, or enjoy a picnic and then return home with memories to last a lifetime. Whether you’ve come from near or far to be here today by taking the time to explore White Sands you have become part of the White Sands community!
audioDescription: From the parking lot, the hard-packed dirt trail leads through the split-rail fence, past a three-sided kiosk with informational signs, and then across flat grassland to the white dunes. The trail then ascends up the sand between two dunes to a wayside sign, where the loop trail then splits to the left and the right. The trail is marked by flat, four-inch wide, blue posts marked with a three-leaved clover symbol. The trail meanders up and down the dunes, which are dotted with a variety of grasses, bushes, and the occasional small tree. The footing varies from hard-packed dirt to soft sand. The parking lot is a loop and is adjacent to the vault toilets. At the beginning of the trail near the parking lot, a brown sign reads, “Dune Life Nature Trail. This one-mile loop trail winds through the edge of the white sands, where dune life is most abundant. Watch for the tracks left behind by various desert animals as they hunt for food among the dunes. Two steep climbs will be encountered on this walk. Summer temperatures can exceed 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Take plenty of water and protect your skin from the sun. Please lock your car.” Further down the trail, another sign warns, “Stop – Stay Alive. Water is required for this trail. Take 64 ounces or two liters of water for each person in your group. When your water is half gone, return to your car. Warning Dangerous to hike above 85 degrees Fahrenheit.” End of description.

title: Pets at White Sands
listingDescription: Pets love White Sands! To them, it's full of new scents, sights, cool, soft sand, and excitement! You'll love bringing your furry companions with you to the park, too.as long as they are non-disruptive, on a leash no longer than six feet, and are under physical control at all times.

images.altText: Two people walking a dog silhouetted by the sunset on a sand dune.
images.title: Pets at White Sands
images.caption: Responsibly enjoy White Sands with your pet.

bodyText:
Pets love White Sands! To them, it's full of new scents, sights, cool, soft sand, and excitement! You'll love bringing your furry companions with you to the park, too.as long as they are non-disruptive, on a leash no longer than six feet, and are under physical control at all times.

We ask you to follow these simple rules for everyone's enjoyment and safety:

Pick up after your pet.
Please help keep White Sands clean and beautiful for your enjoyment and for the enjoyment of future generations. Cleaning up after your pet allows the area to remain sanitary and keeps diseases from spreading—helping to keep you and your family as well as your pet safe and healthy! Please consider the many people who walk barefoot, play, and sled in the sand—no one wants to step or sled into pet waste.

For your added convenience, White Sands National Park has two designated pet walking stations complete with pet poop pick-up bags to help facilitate with the removal of pet excrement. Both are located outside the visitor center;one is adjacent to the women's restroom and the other is behind the picnic tables.

Keep pets on a leash.
Leashing your pet ensures your much-loved friend doesn't run away and get lost. It also prevents them from tangling with hazards such as cacti and rattlesnakes. Federal law prohibits dogs from being off the leash in public areas (36 CFR 2.15). The leash can be no longer than six feet (2 m).

Give pets plenty of water.
Like you, pets get thirsty too. Especially in the summer pets can become dehydrated very quickly. They can also suffer from heat stroke and die.

Do not bring pets inside the visitor center.
While we love seeing pets in the park, they are not allowed in federal buildings (36 CFR 2.15).

Do not leave pets unattended, especially in vehicles.
It is prohibited to leave a pet unattended and tied to an object (36 CFR 2.15).

Temperatures at White Sands National Park can reach extreme highs. Pets should never be left alone inside your vehicle. Within just ten minutes, the inside vehicle temperature will become 25 degrees warmer than the outside temperature. Within 30 minutes, inside temperatures can rise over 30 degrees. Pets left unattended in hot vehicles have suffered severe organ damage or even death.


Service Animals
Service animals are allowed in all facilities and on all trails unless an area has been closed by the superintendent to protect park resources.

Definition of Service Animal
The 2010 revision to Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) defines a "service animal" as a dog that has been individually trained to do work or perform tasks for the benefit of an individual with a disability, including a physical, sensory, psychiatric, intellectual, or other mental disability.

Dogs which are not trained to perform tasks to mitigate the effects of a disability, including dogs used purely to provide comfort or emotional support ("therapy animals"), are considered pets.

You'll love bringing your furry companions with you to the park, too.as long as they are non-disruptive, on a leash no longer than six feet, and are under physical control at all times.

title: Playa Trail
listingDescription: This is one of the easiest trails found at White Sands National Park, and takes visitors to a view of a dried lakebed.

images.altText: An aerial view of the Playa Trail.
images.title: Playa Trail Aerial Photo
images.caption: The Playa Trail is an easy, flat trail at White Sands.

bodyText:
The Playa Trail is an easy, 0.5 mile (800m) round-trip, level trail with outdoor exhibits along the way to help you learn and explore this trail and the characteristics that make it special. Follow the green trail markers with a heart symbol that lead to a small playa. On this self-guided trail, you will discover the importance of a playa undergoing constant change. Learn how this change creates habitats for plants and animals. It may be brown, white, filled with water, or have growing crystals. See what the playa looks like today! At the end of the trail, you have the opportunity to travel back in time and see what this area looked like 10,000 years ago and learn about the giants that once roamed this land. Please stay on the trail. Footprints destroy the biological soil crust that is vital to White Sands. The average completion time is 30 minutes.

Length: 0.5 mile (800m), round-trip
Trail Marker Color: Green
 Trail Marker Symbol: Heart
Average Completion Time: 30 minutes
Difficulty: Easy
 Distance from Visitor Center: 2.5 miles (4 km)
Restroom: No restroom facility is available

Before setting out on foot at White Sands National Park, please view our Hiking Safety Tips.
audioDescription: This trail begins at a gravel-covered pull out along the road that leads into the dunes. Flat land lies on both sides of the road here, covered with grasses and small, woody shrubs between two and two and a half feet tall. Low dune ridges lie to the west and the north, white with splotches of vegetation. The trail is marked by a flat, four inch wide, green posts with a heart symbol. The hard-packed trail leads to the east, along the edge of a flat playa basin on the left, or northern side. The basin itself may hold water or be dry, exposing the bottom in colors that will vary from almost white to darker tan, depending on moisture and other weather conditions.

title: Primrose Picnic Area
listingDescription: This is one of three picnic areas at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Primrose Picnic Area at sunset.
images.title: Primrose Picnic Area
images.caption: The Primrose and Roadrunner Picnic Areas are located next to each other along Dunes Drive.

bodyText:
The Primrose Picnic Area is one of three designated picnic locations at White Sands National Park. Tables are available on a first-come, first-served basis, with metal shade structures attached to each table. There are typically plenty of picnic tables for everyone to enjoy. Some tables are ADA accessible, and each has an elevated grill. 

Tips for a great picnic:

  • Use colored plates, napkins, cups, and silverware. White, plastic dinnerware is not easily visible on the white sand. Remember to Leave No Trace.
  • When you are done with your picnic, use our recycling bins by the vault toilets to recycle plastic and aluminum.
  • Consider using reusable tableware to reduce the amount trash left behind in the park.
  • Trash dumpsters are provided in the picnic areas for your use. If the small trash cans are full please throw trash in the large dumpsters.
  • Bag your trash. Wind will pick up things like paper plates and napkins and carry them into the dunes.

For more information on picnic opportunities at White Sands, please visit our Picnicking Information page.
audioDescription: The Primrose Picnic Area is a large parking lot found just off of Dunes Drive, which is surrounded by rolling white dunes. Within the parking lot are many picnic tables with curved metal shade structures connected to the concrete squares the tables are affixed to. The tables are designed to fit around 4-6 people, and there are about a dozen in this area. The tables range in location from right up against dunes that are anywhere from ten to thirty feet high, to off to the side of the road next to smaller, rolling dunes. The white, hard-packed gypsum sand road that Primrose Picnic Area is on connects to Roadrunner Picnic Area, a much larger lot with similar views.

quickFacts.value: About 6 miles from the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Primrose Picnic Area Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of many restrooms at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Primrose Picnic Area restroom, located near several picnic tables.
images.title: Primrose Picnic Area Restroom
images.caption: The Primrose Picnic Area restroom is in the heart of the dunefield.

bodyText: The Primrose Picnic Area restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, a dumpster, and trash and recycling bins. It is within a large parking area with plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs, and there are accessible parking spaces directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is in a large gypsum sand parking lot, surrounded by rolling white dunes, picnic tables, and a gypsum road leading towards the Roadrunner Picnic Area. There is sparse vegetation scattered throughout, and next to the restroom is a blue recycling unit and a large dark brown dumpster.

title: Rare Wonder Roadside Exhibit
listingDescription: This is one of several interpretive waysides along Dunes Drive at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The "Rare Wonder" wayside along Dunes Drive.
images.title: "Rare Wonder" Wayside
images.caption: The "Rare Wonder" wayside is located about halfway along Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The "Rare Wonder" wayside, located along Dunes Drive, showcases a few of the ways visitors can experience White Sands National Park.
audioDescription: This 4-foot by 2-foot sign is mounted two wooden posts in a wide parking area next to the road in to the heart of the dunes. Both the parking lot and the road are hard-packed sand, bordered by low, white sand dunes. The surrounding sand has spotty vegetation, grasses and bushes with a lone yucca plant here and there. The top half of the panel features an aerial view of this area showing the entrance road winding its way from the highway at the right into the heart of the dunes at the left, where it makes a loop. Labels at the top identify the changing landscape from the brown-colored Chihuahuan desert at the right, through a changing innerdunal zone, where the brown shows streaks of white, into the heart of the dunes which is totally white. A label marks your current location about half way between the edge of the desert and the loop at the end of the road. Across the middle of the panel is text in both English and Spanish that reads, “You are entering a rare wonder. Explore this white world of gypsum sand.” The bottom part of the panel shows an elevated view of the white dunes stretching towards the mountains along the horizon. Two hot air ballons hover near the ground, one dark blue, the other a light grey. Smaller inset photographs highlight activities in the dune. One at the left side, labeled “Explore,” shows two women with backpacks following a trail of footsteps through the white landscape. In the middle, another picture shows two men and a woman, lying side by side in the sand, looking out at us. The label says, “Connect.” To the right of that is a picture of an open hand, covered with sand. The label reads, “Feel.” At the right is a picture of a young boy sliding down a slope in a green, plastic sled, bare feet raised high. The label reads, “Play.” More text reads, “White Sands offers you an other-worldly experience like no other place on the planet. Take time to experience the heart of the dunes—a place so vast astronauts can see it from space.”

title: Riddles in the Sand
listingDescription: This interpretive sign highlights some of the many different types of tracks found in the sand at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: Interpretive sign detailing the different types of tracks found on the sand.
images.title: Riddles in the Sand
images.caption: Everything leaves tracks in the sand. What tracks will you discover?

bodyText: Tracks in the sand offer a fun adventure. What creature has left the marks you see? Was it an animal or a stick rolling down the dunes? These tracks only last for a short while after they are made so make sure to keep an eye out so you don't miss any of them.
audioDescription: This 4-foot by 2-foot sign is mounted on the railing under the tent shelter along the boardwalk. The background picture shows white sand dune sloping down to the left. Leading away from us is a line of indentations in the sand, each with a sandy bar running across it. Text asks us to guess what made these tracks. At the bottom corner, the answer is written upside down – humans. Across the middle of the panel are 9 vertical pictures of different tracks made in the sand. Along the bottom of the panel are 9 square flaps, each with a picture of an animal on it. At the top is text in both English and Spanish, which reads, “Take a close look at the sand around you. What do you see? Chances are that a number of tiny footprints are scattered about, leading from one plant to another. Because most animals here are nocturnal, we usually see only the tracks they leave behind.” “Who made these tracks? Lift the flap to find the answer.” The first set of tracks is made of two parallel lines of small dots. These were made by a buckmoth caterpillar, a green caterpillar with a black stripe down its body. Track number two has two paw prints, each with four toes that end in a claw. These were made by kit fox, a small fox with large, triangular ears. It has a brown back with red neck and forelegs. Track number three shows a straight line of prints, each one made of four dots. Two dots are close together, flanked by two larger ones just above and on either side of them. These were made by the Apache pocket mouse, a small, tan-colored mouse with a hairless tail and large black eye. Track number four shows two lines made of prints of three dots in a cluster. These were made by the shiny black darkling beetle with its long legs. Track number five consists of a line in the sand with alternating footprints on either side. Each has a central pad and five long toes. These were made by the bleached earless lizard, with its white skin. Track number six has small prints that look like human feet with two small indentations in between and a short line extending below. These were made by Merriam’s kangaroo rat, a small furry creature with long hind legs and short front legs. Track number seven is a long, squiggly line in the sand. It belongs to the black-tailed rattlesnake, its brown body covered in darker diamond shapes. Track number 8 is a set of prints like a capital “Y” with a vertical line through it. These were made by the horned lark, a plump bird with a brown back, white breast and a yellow throat framed with black bands. The last track is made of prints that have three toes extending forward and two lines extending backward like an upside down “V.” These were made by the greater roadrunner, bird with a long narrow beak, a crest on its head and a very long thin tail.

title: Roadrunner Picnic Area
listingDescription: This is the largest picnic area at White Sands National Park, and the only one with a large pavilion that doesn't require a reservation.

images.altText: A view of the Primrose and Roadrunner Picnic Areas at White Sands National Park.
images.title: Roadrunner & Primrose Picnic Area
images.caption: Roadrunner and Primrose Picnic Areas are near each other along the same pullout on Dunes Drive.

bodyText:
The Roadrunner Picnic Area is one of three designated picnic locations at White Sands National Park. Tables are available on a first-come, first-served basis, with metal shade structures attached to each table. There are typically plenty of picnic tables for everyone to enjoy. Some tables are ADA accessible, and each has an elevated grill. In addition to dozens of tables, the Roadrunner Picnic Area has two picnic pavilions that can accommodate groups of up to 20 individuals. These pavilions are also available on a first-come, first-served basis.

Tips for a great picnic:

  • Use colored plates, napkins, cups, and silverware. White, plastic dinnerware is not easily visible on the white sand. Remember to Leave No Trace.
  • When you are done with your picnic, use our recycling bins by the vault toilets to recycle plastic and aluminum.
  • Consider using reusable tableware to reduce the amount trash left behind in the park.
  • Trash dumpsters are provided in the picnic areas for your use. If the small trash cans are full please throw trash in the large dumpsters.
  • Bag your trash. Wind will pick up things like paper plates and napkins and carry them into the dunes.

For more information on picnic opportunities at White Sands, please visit our Picnicking Information page.
audioDescription: The Roadrunner Picnic Area is a large parking lot found just past the Primrose Picnic Area, and is surrounded by rolling white dunes. Within the parking lot are many picnic tables with curved metal shade structures connected to the concrete squares the tables are affixed to. The tables are designed to fit around 4-6 people, and there are over twenty in this area. The tables range in location from right up against dunes that are anywhere from ten to thirty feet high, to off to the side of the road next to smaller, rolling dunes. They're arranged in lines running parallel to the tallest nearby dunes. There is a large covered pavilion with two metal charcoal grills with lids on one side and an uncovered, smaller grill on the other. Underneath the shade structure are several stone picnic tables, and there are two stone trashcans in separate corners of the pavilion. The white, hard-packed gypsum sand road that Roadrunner Picnic Area is on connects to Primrose Picnic Area, a much smaller lot with similar views.

title: Safety at White Sands
listingDescription: To get the most out of your experience, please read and follow the safety guidelines.

images.altText: Bolt of lighting strikes white sand dune
images.title: Weather in the Tularosa Basin.
images.caption: Weather in the Tularosa Basin can change quickly. Visitors need to be prepared.

bodyText:
Bring plenty of food and water

You will need more water than you think. Sweat evaporates quickly. Your body loses water rapidly in the desert. Always carry extra water with you. When your water is half-gone, return to your car.

One gallon (4 Liters) of water per person per day is recommended, as well as high-energy snacks such as fruit, nuts, and energy bars. Fill up water containers at the visitor center. There is no water available in the dunefield.

In addition, it is important to balance food intake with fluid consumption, lest you run the risk of becoming dangerously debilitated and severely ill. Hyponatremia may occur when a person drinks too much water without replenishing electrolytes or eating salts. If a member of your party begins to experience nausea, muscle cramps, or disorientation, yet they are well hydrated, they may need salt. Crackers, pretzels, and sports drinks should be consumed to keep up sodium levels in the body.
 


Bring a fully charged cell phone

Start your day with a fully-charged cell phone. Bring a portable charger if you have one. There are no outlets for charging cell phones at the park. Turn your cell phone off or put in airplane mode while walking in the dunes. Conserving your battery for emergencies could mean the difference between life or death.

 


In an Emergency Call 911

Data and cellular signal strength can vary drastically throughout the park. Sometimes you can text when you are unable to make a call. In an emergency situation with limited cell reception, text a friend and have him call 911 for you. You may not be able to call 911 if you are using a cell phone from outside the United Sates. Consult your mobile service provider for instructions on how to access emergency services with your device prior to venturing out into the dunes.

 


Have a Plan and Share It

Tell someone who is not in your party where you are going and when you will return. Know the weather forecast and what time the sun sets. Be prepared for the weather and ensure you have enough time to complete your hike.

 


Hike with Friends

It is not recommended to hike alone. Always keep your children in sight. Children can wander, and separating from your companions can mean getting lost.

 


Know Where You Are

It is easy to become disoriented in the dunefield. Wind moves sand and erases your tracks. GPS can be unreliable. While hiking, pay attention to and follow trail posts, each marked with a specific color and symbol. Knowing the trail markers is critical if you become lost. Look carefully for the next trail marker before continuing. If you cannot see the next marker, do not continue, turn around and return to your car. Plan your hike so that you are back at the trailhead before sunset.

 


Do Not Wander if Lost

Carry a park map and compass and keep landmarks, such as water towers, in view. If you become lost, stop and sit on top of a dune. Wandering can endanger your life and make finding you more difficult. Use a mirror or piece of aluminum foil to flash sunlight towards potential rescuers. Call 911.

 


Be Prepared

The sun reflecting off the white sand is intense year round and can cause severe sunburns. Wear a hat, sunscreen with an SPF of 15 or higher, and sunglasses. Apply sunscreen to all exposed areas, even in winter. Wear clothing that is appropriate for the day’s weather: loose, light-colored clothing during warmer months, and warm clothing during cooler seasons. Remember that temperatures can drop drastically after sunset – anywhere from 20 to 30 degrees.

In addition, take the park map, a flashlight and extra batteries, a whistle, a signal mirror, a first-aid kit, and extra clothes that can be layered for varying weather.
 


Rest Often

Heat illness can occur fast. Take frequent breaks in the shade. There are picnic areas with sheltered tables along Dunes Drive. You can also bring your own sun shelter or sun umbrella. Exposure to full sunshine can increase heat index values by up to 15°F (9°C). The sun’s UV rays are the strongest at midday. Plan your visit for early morning or late afternoon when the sun is lower.

 


Know Your Limits

Altitude

The elevation at White Sands is 4,235 feet (1,291 m). This may have an effect on those traveling from lower elevations. Allow time for your body to acclimate by adjusting your activity level. Take frequent breaks and drink water. Common symptoms of altitude sickness include headache and loss of appetite. Pace yourself and pay attention to how you are feeling.
audioDescription: Welcome to White Sands National Park, a place of wonder, inspiration, and beauty. With its glittering white backdrop against a vast glowing sky, White Sands offers unforgettable views and fun activities for all, but it is important to safely enjoy the park. Your tomorrow depends on the decisions that you make today. Each year, park rangers respond to dozens of search and rescue incidents in the park. These frequently involve heat exhaustion, dehydration, and injuries. To get the most out of your experience, please read and follow the safety guidelines below.

title: Sledding Area - Alkali Flat Parking Lot

images.altText: White sand dunes with a blue sky background.
images.title: Sledding Area - Alkali Flat Parking Lot
images.caption: Sledding is one of the most popular activities at White Sands National Park.

bodyText:
Alkali Flat trail parking area has dunes meant for the experienced sledder. The steepness of the dunes means you will get some pretty good speed. Make sure there is nothing at the base of the dune where you are going down because it can be difficult to stop and not run into it.

This activity can be done throughout the park. One only has to keep these two things in mind; Don’t sled into plants, for they have a tough enough life as it is in the desert. And second, don’t sled into roads, for it might turn into a dangerous situation.

Bring your own sled or purchase one from the park’s gift shop.

title: Soap of the Desert - EKO Stop 5

images.altText: Soaptree Yucca
images.title: Soaptree Yucca
images.caption: Soaptree Yucca

bodyText: When the dune moves, the stem can no longer hold the plant up, the tall stem will fall. Soon new plants will grow from the fallen stem. The fiber from the spikey leaves can be used in making rope, matting, sandals, or baskets. The roots of the soaptree yucca can be boiled and used as soap. It also provides a food source for animals like the Apache pocket mouse.
audioDescription: Next to the informational sign to the left are three very sharp and pointy Soaptree Yuccas. The leaves are dark green, and the steams that are exposed will have a cork bark texture that is dark brown. Past the plant is a big drop off. It goes down the dune into an interdune area of various grasses. On the right is a slight hill with a few Cottonwood trees.

title: Sometimes Stinky is Best - EKO Stop 7

images.altText: A darkling beetle, standing with its backside in the air in a defensive position.
images.title: A Darkling Beetle
images.caption: A darkling beetle, standing with its backside in the air ready to release its foul-smelling liquid.

bodyText: While the darkling beetles are easy to see against the white sand, they are not defenseless. When scared, the darkling beetle sticks its backside in the air. They will spray a foul-smelling liquid from its posterior to scare off predators. The smell is like an oil-based fuel called kerosene. This smell is not pleasant. As a result, some people incorrectly call them stink bugs!
audioDescription: This area in the fall will have seeding grasses on both sides of a packed natural sand path through the interdune. In early fall, there will still be a few flowers that are yellow. In late spring and summer, the grasses will be green, and the flower colors will vary by plant. Darkling’s frequently feed in this area on decaying plants or already dead insects. If you take a rest anywhere in the dunes, they tend to get curious and will come to see you. They are attracted to moisture.

title: Staying Cool Out of Sight

images.altText: A solitary cottonwood tree grows in the middle with desert shrub and a tall white dune in the back.
images.title: Lone Cottonwood
images.caption: With exposed roots, the cottonwood tree indicates where the dune used to be.

bodyText: The sounds of the dunefield are different at night! A lot of the animals come out when it’s cooler and quieter – no humans. The top predator in the dunefield, the five-pound kit fox, comes out to play and hunt when darkness falls. They live in burrows in the exposed pedestals. Looking around, you probably can’t see any sources of water for these mighty hunters, so where do they get water? Kit foxes don’t drink water the way humans do; they get all the water they need from the blood of the prey they consume.
audioDescription: This sign, about two feet wide and one and one-half feet high, is mounted at an angle on a single metal post. Past the sign as you face it is a dead tree standing at the top of a small ridge. To your left, the trail curves to the left as it skirts the bottom of the small ridge. Behind you is a flat, grass covered basin surrounded by the low dunes. The sign has a picture of Katie, the cartoon fox figure, in the upper left, with text in both English and Spanish along the top. The bottom part of the sign has a picture of a Burrowing Owl perched on a gnarled tree branch. Its back is brown with tan spots. Its head and breast are also tan with a brown cap and a brown mask around its big yellow eyes. Text at the top reads, “Do you have a trick for getting your favorite food? Burrowing owls line their dens with poop from other animals to attract their favorite food—beetles. When bugs show up, they grab them. These owls like to take over foxholes or tunnels of badger or prairie dogs —places rattlesnakes also live. The owls stay out of sight and fake out enemies by hissing and making scary rattlesnake sounds.” End of description.

title: Stories from the Ice Age

images.altText: Tan surface with several darker footprint impressions. A photo scale provides size context
images.title: Human fossilized footprints
images.caption: White Sands has the largest collection of ice age fossilized footprints in the world

bodyText: What drew you to White Sands National Park today? Hiking? Sledding? Solitude? The Tularosa Basin has been a place where we as humans have been coming for thousands of years, even before the dunefield you see today formed. If you had been standing here during the last Ice Age, you would have witnessed a climate that was much cooler, wetter, and greener with a massive lake known as Lake Otero that was the size of the present-day Great Salt Lake in Utah. These were the conditions that lured the Ice Age megafauna like Columbian mammoths, giant ground sloths, dire wolves, camels, and more. This abundance of large game is likely what attracted these early human migrants to this basin. The presence of humans and megafauna at White Sands is not from the discovery of bones or artifacts, but from the preservation of fossilized footprints in the ancient lake sediments. Today, these fossilized footprints have to be cataloged and studied rapidly because as quickly as they appear at the surface, they will continue to erode away with the wind in just a matter of years. These footprints will never tell us everything we want to know about what human and megafauna life at the time was like, but they do provide snapshots. A group of humans stalked a giant ground sloth on a hunt. A woman struggled and slipped through the mud for over a mile with a set of children’s feet appearing occasionally as she briefly sets her child down before moving on. A giant ground sloth made a footprint that became a puddle where children’s footprints show them splashing in the water. Sets of teenagers fossilized footprints carbon-dated to around 23,000 years old, older than any definitive evidence of human habitation yet found in North America. What will be remembered about your visit to White Sands today?
audioDescription: From the trailhead pull-off, a trail sign with the title reads " " and gives a description of the human and megafauna life that lived here during the ice age. The trail is marked by green posts with heart symbols on them. The trail begins in desert scrubland vegetation and leads towards a dry lake bed with a bright white surface where evaporite minerals have been left behind. Across the park road there is more desert scrubland before it meets the white sand dunes with sparse vegetation. The trailhead and a brown restroom building are also visible.

title: Sunset Stroll Meeting Area
listingDescription: This is the meeting place for the Sunset Stroll guided Ranger hike.

images.altText: The Sunset Stroll parking area, with several cars in the lot.
images.title: Sunset Stroll Parking Area
images.caption: Sunset Stroll is the perfect time to hike with a Ranger and catch the sunset.

bodyText:
Meet here for the Sunset Stroll evening program, which is offered daily during normal park operations.

The Sunset Stroll is a leisurely, ranger-guided stroll through the gypsum sand dunes. It is a splendid opportunity to experience the dunes first-hand while learning about the uniqueness of our geology, plants, and animals. As an added bonus, the stroll is timed to end at sunset, providing a panoramic view of the sun setting over the mountains and the potential for some breath-taking photographic opportunities.
audioDescription: The area is a pull-out located just off of Dunes Drive, which is made of hard-packed gypsum sand. The pullout itself can fit about 20 cars parked perpendicular to the edge of the road. Just beyond the parking area are simple brown wooden fences. Vegetation is scattered throughout the rolling white dunes that surround the parking area, including various grasses and the soaptree yucca.

quickFacts.value: About 5.5 miles from the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Take a Deep Breath

images.altText: A pale green bush grows on white sand with vegetation dotted dunes in the background.
images.title: Rosemary Mint
images.caption: Rosemary mint is abundant in the park, see if you spot it anywhere else on your journey!

bodyText: While you’re in the park today, you may notice rock-like mounds dotting the dunes. These are pedestals! Rosemary mint is one of the main plants that creates pedestals. Plants create them by pulling water to their roots and holding it tight. As the dunes move, the pedestals are uncovered and hardened by the sun. Once uncovered, the pedestals begin their second life as homes for the animals that live in the dunefield.
audioDescription: This sign, about two feet wide and one and one-half feet high, is mounted at an angle on a single metal post. It is mounted just down the slope from a small clump of scrubby cottonwood trees. The trees are short, almost bush-like in appearance with white bark and broad leaves that are almost heart-shaped. Past the sign as you face it, the trail continues downslope as the small ridge you are on drops down to a brush-covered flat basin. To the right the sand is broad and smooth. To the left, the side of the dune ridge falls off very steeply just past a group of yucca plants with their sword-like leaves. The sign has a picture of Katie, the cartoon fox figure, in the upper left, with text in both English and Spanish along the top. The bottom part of the sign has a picture of a brown bat, lying on the ground with wings folded, a large black insect in its mouth. Labels identify the animals as the Pallid Bat and the Darkling Beetle. Text at the top reads, “Most bats eat while they fly. But my pallid bat friends are not most bats. They like to crunch down on big bugs that almost never fly—crickets, cicadas, stinkbugs, and scorpions. Since their food is rarely up in the air, it is not strange to see pallid bats having their dinner on the ground. Darkling beetles (stinkbugs) are chock-full of protein and fat, BUT there is that AWFUL smell.” End of description.

title: The Result of Geologic Coincidences

images.altText: In the foreground, rolling white dunes. The San Andres Mountains sit above the dunes at sunrise
images.title: San Andres Mountains at Sunrise
images.caption: The mountains that ring this basin contain the gypsum layers that make up the sand dunes today

bodyText: Have you ever felt that things fell into place perfectly for you? For the unusual dunes you see to form, the perfect sequence of geologic events had to occur here. Gypsum, the material that makes up the sand dunes, is among the most common on earth and is widely used as a construction material in drywall, plaster of Paris, and concrete. Despite gypsum being found on all seven continents, this place is worthy of being a National Park because gypsum sand dunes are among the rarest geologic features on earth, with only 3 in the entire world! The process of building this geologic wonder has been a long time in the making. In the mountains to the east or west, you may see lighter layers. This is gypsum! It was deposited 280 million years ago by a shallow inland sea that advanced and receded across the southwest, leaving behind the massive deposits of gypsum that make up the white sand today. Flash forward to 70 million years ago when colliding plate tectonics uplifted the horizontal gypsum layers in a massive mountain building event. Around 20 to 30 million years ago these plate tectonics began to pull apart creating the two separate mountain ranges you see today, the San Andres Mountains in the west and the Sacramento Mountains in the east. In between the mountain ranges where you now stand the earth fell away forming the Tularosa Basin. Finally, the ancient Rio Grande River flowed into the Tularosa Basin between 2 and 3 million years ago bringing with it sediments that eventually blocked any water carrying gypsum from flowing out of the basin. Later in this tour, you’ll explore the modern geologic forces that have sculpted these dunes, but without the perfect series of geologic coincidences to set the stage none of this would be possible.
audioDescription: From the road pull off, a two lane park road continues towards the dunefield. The basin extends flat to the east with green and brown, low lying, desert scrubland vegetation. In the distance, there are some buildings at Holloman Air Force Base and then the town of Alamogordo further out. The Sacramento Mountains rise several thousand feet above the basin floor. Across the park road to the west, 20 foot tall white dunes rise up from the scrubland vegetation and is dotted with few green plants.

title: Tularosa Basin Roadside Exhibit
listingDescription: This is one of several interpretive waysides along Dunes Drive at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The "Tularosa Basin" wayside along Dunes Drive.
images.title: "Tularosa Basin" Wayside
images.caption: The "Tularosa Basin" wayside is the first interpretive panel along Dunes Drive.

bodyText: The "Tularosa Basin" wayside, located along Dunes Drive, offers information about the basin and its water-storing properties.
audioDescription: This 4-foot by 2-foot sign is mounted on two wooden posts at the edge of a pullout along the road that winds its way into the heart of the dunes. The land behind the sign is flat, scrub-covered desert land, stretching out to the distant mountains in the east. On the other side of the road is a narrow strip of brush-covered land backed by low dunes with low, bushy vegetation on their slopes. The top half of the panel features an aerial view of this area showing the entrance road winding its way from the highway at the right into the heart of the dunes at the left, where it makes a loop. Labels at the top identify the changing landscape from the brown-colored Chihuahuan desert at the right, through a changing innerdunal zone, where the brown shows streaks of white, into the heart of the dunes which is totally white. A label marks your current location near the entrance to the park. Across the middle of the panel is text in both English and Spanish that reads, “You are in the Tularosa Basin. This basin is like a bathtub with no drain. Water, the essential ingredient in dune formation and stabilization, drains down towards White Sands, the lowest point. Without water, the dunes would not exist.” The bottom half of the panel shows a high aerial view of the basin with the snow-topped San Andres Mountains at the left and the Sacramento Mountains to the right. The basin is brown with a huge patch of white stretching from the center back to the left. A label identifies White Sands National Monument with the entrance road in the lower right of the patch marked in red. Wide blue arrows point from the mountains into the white area.

title: West Filming Area
listingDescription: This is one of several large parking areas at White Sands, and a great place to sled.

images.altText: A large parking area surrounded by white gypsum sand dunes.
images.title: West Filming Area
images.caption: The West Filming Area parking lot at sunset.

bodyText:
The West Filming Area is both a place to park and a popular spot for sledding. A portion of the area is located behind a locked gate, and is only accessible by vehicle with prior authorization.

Visit the Commercial Filming and Photography page on our website to learn more about some of the ways this space can be utilized.
audioDescription: The West Filming Area is essentially two large circular parking lots, connected by a thin, gypsum sand road. The largest lot is behind a locked metal gate, but is accessible on foot year round. The lots are hard-packed sand, and are surrounded by rolling white gypsum sand dunes. There is sparse vegetation scattered throughout, including soaptree yuccas and various plants and grasses.

quickFacts.value: About 7 miles from the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: White Sands Amphitheater
listingDescription: This is the amphitheater at White Sands National Park, where large evening programs and events take place.

images.altText: Full Moon Night at the White Sands amphitheater, just before sunset.
images.title: Full Moon Night at White Sands
images.caption: Full Moon Night at the White Sands amphitheater.

bodyText:
The amphitheater is where many fun events and Ranger-led programs are held, like Full Moon Nights and MothaPalooza. While the amphitheater doesn't have built-in seating, it is a large, flat area surrounded by dunes. Visitors are welcome to bring their own seating, blankets, and comfort items for when they sit on the dunes and watch the show.

For more information about programs at White Sands, visit the Park Ranger Programs page on our website.
audioDescription: The amphitheater is a spacious area within the dunefield. It consists of rolling white dunes surrounding a large flat area, called the interdune area. The dunes are between twenty and thirty feet tall, which allows visitors to find seating on the dunes and look down at the makeshift stage created in the interdune area. There is sparse vegetation scattered throughout, and a simple brown wooden fence separating the flat part of the amphitheater from the parking area. There is also a white storage trailer parked on the edge of the interdune portion of the amphitheater.

title: White Sands Entrance Station
listingDescription: This is the only location where entrance passes are sold at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The entrance station at White Sands National Park.
images.title: White Sands Entrance Station
images.caption: This entrance station is the only location to buy daily and annual places at White Sands.

bodyText:
This entrance station is where visitors can purchase passes for White Sands National Park itself, as well as America the Beautiful interagency passes, when available.

For more information about entering White Sands, please visit our Fees & Passes page.
audioDescription: The entrance station is located one-quarter of a mile into the park on Dunes Drive. Built in a common southwest style, it has adobe walls and a flat roof. It is shaped like two rectangles side by side, the one closer to the road being slightly taller and narrower. On the front and side there is a shade roof attached to the sides of the building consisting of small logs laid on two-inch thick supporting beams. The shade roof is a dark brown and the walls are a desert tan, which has a slight pinkish cast to it. The area around the building is landscaped with smooth, fist-sized rocks and there is a flag pole in front flying the American flag. Just to the east of the building is a similar, smaller structure, which allows for two lanes of traffic going into the park during busy times.

title: White Sands Group Use Area
listingDescription: This is the only area in the park with picnic tables designed to accommodate large groups.

images.altText: A large group use picnic pavilion, with separate picnic tables surrounding it.
images.title: Group Use Area
images.caption: The group use area has plenty of room for large gatherings at White Sands.

bodyText:
From family reunions to weddings to scout jamborees, White Sands National Park has long been a popular meeting place for large gatherings. Our group use area is the perfect location for private functions, and is available for reservation during normal park operations.

For more information on how to reserve White Sands' group use area and the amenities it offers, please visit the Group Use Area information page.
audioDescription: The group use area is a large parking lot surrounded by rolling white dunes. Within the parking lot are several picnic tables with curved metal shade structures connected to the concrete squares the tables are affixed to. The tables are designed to fit around 4-6 people, and there are around 10 in the group use area. In the center of the lot is a large covered picnic pavilion with two metal charcoal grills with lids on one side and an uncovered, smaller grill on the other. Underneath the shade structure are several stone picnic tables, and there are two stone trashcans in separate corners of the pavilion.

title: White Sands Trading Company
listingDescription: This is the only place at White Sands National Park where visitors can purchase sleds and select souvenirs.

images.altText: The White Sands Trading Company gift shop on a sunny day.
images.title: White Sands Trading Company
images.caption: The White Sands Trading Company sells snacks, sleds, and various souvenirs.

bodyText:
White Sands Trading (WST), official concessioner of White Sands National Park and a New Mexico family-owned company, is proud to join with the National Park Service in preserving this rich ecosystem for generations to come. We are vigilant in using best practices to limit our impact on the environment and to educate visitors about the fragility of this unique area.

Since 2005, the White Sands Trading Gift Shop has been providing visitors with unique mementos of White Sands National Park. We offer authentic Native American handcrafts from New Mexico including intricately detailed pottery and sterling silver jewelry. Visitors of all ages enjoy our sand disks while sledding down the dunes. Our grab-and-go area will satisfy your hunger with sandwiches and snacks. You can also restock your water or choose from a variety of beverages. A varied selection of t-shirts and souvenirs will help you memorialize your visit to the largest gypsum dunefield on earth.

WST pays a franchise fee of 16% of our gross receipts to the park. This money is used to make improvements within the park. We appreciate your support and look forward to continuing our mission of preserving the historic building we occupy while protecting the unparalleled desert-scape of White Sands National Park.
audioDescription: The Gift Shop is adjacent to the veranda located at the rear of the Visitor Center and is made of the same adobe construction as the Visitor Center with red tile floors inside. The glass-paned double-door-entrance may be accessed from the courtyard veranda or from the rear parking lot. Both entrances have an uneven threshold, due to the historical structure of the building. Inside, there are three connecting rooms with multiple counters, shelving and hanging displays.

title: White Sands Water Station
listingDescription: As the only drinking water fill station at White Sands National Park, this is arguably one of the most important locations in the park.

images.altText: The water fill station, which is located on the west side of the Visitor Center complex.
images.title: White Sands Water Fill Station
images.caption: This fill station contains the only available drinking water at White Sands National Park.

bodyText:
This is White Sands National Park's only water bottle filling station, located near the restrooms and picnic tables at the Visitor Center complex. There is no water available in the dunefield.

You will need more water than you think. Sweat evaporates quickly, and your body loses water rapidly in the desert. Always carry extra water with you. One gallon (4 Liters) of water per person per day is recommended.
audioDescription: Adjacent to the two shaded picnic tables near the edge of the sidewalk next to the visitor center is a water fountain. On the right is a tall column with an overhead spigot for filling water bottles. At the left is a standard drinking fountain. In dry weather, insects will enjoy this water source and bees in particular will gather here. Mounted on the posts behind the fountain is a two foot by one foot sign with a picture of the fountain and text that reads, “Free Water. It can be brutally HOT in the dunefield. You need water. The is the last place to get it. Fill your own bottle or buy one from our store. Either way, you will keep disposable bottles out of our national park and out of landfills. You will find no water past this visitor center. Last Chance! Fill your bottle now.”

title: White Sands on the Big Screen
listingDescription: Does White Sands look familiar to you? This next stop might explain why.

images.altText: Cinematographers film a mid-1900s vehicle in the dunefield.
images.title: Car Commercial Filming
images.caption: White Sands has been a popular place for commercial filming since its designation as a Monument.

bodyText:
Do you get a sense of déjà vu as you amble through this picturesque pile of sand? That vaguely familiar feeling might be rooted in seeing White Sands on the big screen, mid-90s MTV, or even as the backdrop of an advertisement for your favorite car. Since 1950, this park has been featured in dozens of films, ranging from classic spaghetti Westerns to modern action, science fiction, documentaries, and comedy movies. On top of being a great spot for yoga instructors to film their classes, this dunefield was even used in a promotion for the Olympics.

Whether it’s rugged cowboys or old school boybands that pique your interest, it’s possible you’ve followed along some famous footsteps on your hike today. Take a closer look at the landscape the next time you spot some dunes in a video, too – it might be White Sands that you’re watching!

Want to see White Sands on the big screen sooner rather than later? Swing by the Visitor Center to watch our captivating 17-minute orientation film, which is shown every half hour, on the hour. If the Visitor Center isn’t showing the film, the DVD is available for sale at the non-profit park store.
audioDescription: The trail is marked by flat, four inch wide, orange posts with a spade symbol. From the kiosk, it follows a low ridge on the right, across a flat area, then up a slope to a sign where the trail splits to make a loop. That sign has a map of where the camp sites are located around the loop, sites 1 – 5 to the right and 6 – 10 to the left. At that point you are surrounded by the white dunes rising and falling on all sides, with distant mountains visible both to the west and the east. The dunes are bare white sand, often with ripples across their surface. In between are small flat basins with some clumps of grass, small bushes and an occasional yucca plant.

quickFacts.value: About 100 feet from the Backcountry Camping Loop Trailhead
quickFacts.name: Location

title: White on White

images.altText: A completely white lizard with small black dots on its sides blends into the white sands
images.title: Bleached earless lizard adaptation
images.caption: The bleached earless lizard is one of more than 60 species found only in the White Sands dunes

bodyText: You are now at Interdune Boardwalk. On the signs detailing the trail, you will also see an overhead picture of the dunes. Imagine you are a bird of prey soaring over the dunes searching for a tasty snack in the form of a lizard or small rodent. As you look down on the endless waves of white dunes you might think that the dunefield is entirely barren other than the yuccas and rosemary mint dotting the landscape. However, darting in the interdune are small, white color adapted critters doing their best to go unseen. White Sands provides one of the best examples on earth of rapid adaptation to a unique environment. These white sand dunes have only been here for around 7,000 years and in such a short time the animals that call them home have shown remarkable adaptation to their environment. Unlike the surrounding desert, at White Sands it is survival of the lightest! Over generations, certain traits like color give animals an advantage in a given environment and pass on their advantageous traits to their descendants. Here you’ll find that being white color adapted not only helps an animal hide from predators, but it also keeps them cool in the scorching summers by reflecting sunlight away. The rapid change in habitat in the Tularosa Basin has led to an explosion of white, endemic species found nowhere else on earth. Just as isolated islands lead to unique, specialized species of animals, the unusual environment of the dunefield has led to lizards, moths, mammals, and even a species of fish that are found only at White Sands.
audioDescription: From the trailhead parking lot, there is a trail kiosk which has information about " ". In the parking lot there is also a brown restroom building. The trail is an accessible, raised, metal boardwalk with rails which leads into the interdune area with grasses and flowers growing on either side of the trail. The trail continues for a quarter mile into the dunes. Midway on the boardwalk there is a tan shade structure with benches for seating. At the end of the trail, the landscape becomes open white sand dunes rolling into the distance with sparse plants like soaptree yuccas, rosemary mints, and sumacs dotting the dunes.

title: Yucca Picnic Area
listingDescription: One of three picnic areas at White Sands National Park. The Yucca picnic is a small picnic area that is the closest to the Backcountry Camping loop trail and Alkali Flat trail parking areas.

images.altText: Picnic tables in the Yucca Picnic Area.
images.title: Yucca Picnic Area
images.caption: The Yucca Picnic Area has several picnic tables available for use.

bodyText:
The Yucca Picnic Area is one of three designated picnic locations at White Sands National Park. Tables are available on a first-come, first-served basis, with metal shade structures attached to each table. There are typically plenty of picnic tables for everyone to enjoy. Some tables are ADA accessible, and each has an elevated grill. 

Tips for a great picnic:

  • Use colored plates, napkins, cups, and silverware. White, plastic dinnerware is not easily visible on the white sand. Remember to Leave No Trace.
  • When you are done with your picnic, use our recycling bins by the vault toilets to recycle plastic and aluminum.
  • Consider using reusable tableware to reduce the amount trash left behind in the park.
  • Trash dumpsters are provided in the picnic areas for your use. If the small trash cans are full please throw trash in the large dumpsters.
  • Bag your trash. Wind will pick up things like paper plates and napkins and carry them into the dunes.

For more information on picnic opportunities at White Sands, please visit our Picnicking Information page.
audioDescription: The Yucca Picnic Area is a large parking lot found just off of Dunes Drive, which is surrounded by rolling white dunes. Within the parking lot are several picnic tables with curved metal shade structures connected to the concrete squares the tables are affixed to. The tables are designed to fit around 4-6 people, and there are around 5 arranged in a circle around the restroom.

quickFacts.value: About 6.5 miles from the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Yucca Picnic Area Restroom
listingDescription: This is one of several restrooms at White Sands National Park.

images.altText: The Yucca Picnic Area restroom in the center of a ring of picnic tables.
images.title: Yucca Picnic Area Restroom
images.caption: The Yucca Picnic Area restroom is in the center of a group of picnic tables arranged in a circle.

bodyText: The Yucca Picnic Area restroom has two separate wheelchair-accessible vault toilets with no running water, a dumpster, and trash and recycling bins. It is within a large picnic area with plenty of space to park automobiles and RVs, and there are accessible places to park directly in front of the restroom.
audioDescription: The restroom buildings are house-shaped, with tan wood paneling exteriors and concrete bases. There are two dark brown metal doors on both ends of the buildings, each opening up to a small concrete room with one vault toilet in each. There are two brown cylindrical vents poking out of the roof, one above each toilet. In between both doors are two brown square signs stacked on top of each other, one with a wheelchair denoting accessibility, and the other with female and male stick figures separated by a vertical line and the word "restroom" underneath them. In between the stacked signs is an interpretive sign showing ways visitors can manage their waste and "Help Keep White Sands White." It encourages visitors to throw waste away in the proper receptacles, pick up after their pets, and "take photos, not sand." This restroom in particular is in the center of a round gypsum sand parking lot, and is surrounded by picnic tables. The doors face the parking lot, with views of the picnic tables as well as Dunes Drive. When facing the doors, visitors can see rolling white dunes with minimal vegetation. Next to this restroom is a blue recycling unit and a large dark brown dumpster.
